headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would know like to hand the conference over to T.C. Robillard, Chief I
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would know like to hand the conference over to T.C. Robillard, Chief Investment -- Chief Investor Relations Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands quarterly investor conference call and webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the fourth quarter of 2015. Hopefully, everyone has had a chance to review the new
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands quarterly investor conference call and webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the fourth quarter of 2015. Hopefully, everyone has had a chance to review the news release we issued earlier today. The news release and the replay of the call can be found in the Investor section of our hanes.com  website. 
On the call today, we may make forward-looking statements, either in our prepared remarks or in associated questions-and-answer session. These statements are based on current expectations or beliefs and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. These risks are detailed in our various filings with SEC and may be found on or website as well as in our news releases. The company does not undertake to update or revise any forward-looking statements, which speak only to the time at which they are made. 
Unless otherwise noted, today's references to our consolidated financial results as well as our 2016 guidance exclude all onetime charges and expenses. Additional information, including a reconciliation of these and other non-GAAP performance measures to GAAP, can be found in today's press release. 
With me on the call today are Rich Noll, our Chief Executive Officer; Gerald Evans, our Chief Operating Officer; and Rick Moss, our Chief Financial Officer. 
For today's call, Rich will focus on a few big picture themes, Gerald will focus on key highlights within our business operations and Rick will focus on certain financial aspects of our results. 
I will now turn the call over to Rich.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, T.C. 2015 was another record year for HanesBrands. We grew revenue 8%, operating profit 13% and earnings per share 17%, once again magnifying our growth rate as you walk down the P&L and we intend to do it again in 2016. While these are great r
componenttext:
Thank you, T.C. 2015 was another record year for HanesBrands. We grew revenue 8%, operating profit 13% and earnings per share 17%, once again magnifying our growth rate as you walk down the P&L and we intend to do it again in 2016. While these are great results, make no mistake, they are not up to the high standards to which we hold ourselves at HanesBrands. We did not fully deliver on our Q4 commitments. 
While Q4 was impacted by the well-publicized retail traffic declines, frankly, we struggled a bit on the sales line all last year. So it's time to refine our approach and regain our sales momentum. We have a variety of focused initiatives designed to re-energize sales. These initiatives, which Geral will highlight, gives us confidence in our ability to firmly deliver our 2016 revenue target. 
We also expect another year of double-digit earnings growth, growing EPS 11% to 15%. Importantly, we can achieve the low end of this range just with our expected acquisition synergies, our historical level of SG&A leverage and our projected contributions from share repurchases. 
In terms of cash flow, we have several action plans in place that put us all on track to generate up to $850 million this year, which would be the highest level on our history. To put this in perspective, this is the amount of cumulative cash flow we generated in the first 3 years as a public company. 
Turning to acquisitions. Both DBA, now renamed Hanes Europe, and Knights Apparel, continued to perform extremely well. Operating results were above plan, the integrations are progressing on schedule and we are on target to deliver $40 million in synergies this year. And as I've mentioned last quarter, we have turned our attention to 2016 acquisitions. 
A number of variables obviously need to fall into place. With the integration of Knights Apparel and Hanes Europe now in full swing, we have the bandwidth to take on additional acquisitions. 
So in closing, we are refocusing on driving our top line and we are well positioned for another year of double-digit EPS growth with upside provided by potential future acquisitions. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Gerald.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich. We have a lot of things working very well in our business, such as our innovations, our supply chain efficiencies, our margin enhancement strategies and our acquisitions. And this is evidenced by 3 consecutive years of double-digit growth in
componenttext:
Thanks, Rich. We have a lot of things working very well in our business, such as our innovations, our supply chain efficiencies, our margin enhancement strategies and our acquisitions. And this is evidenced by 3 consecutive years of double-digit growth in both operating profit and earnings per share. However, the fourth quarter did not turn out as we had expected. Retail traffic declined at high-single digit rates in November and the first 3 weeks of December, driven by one of the warmest holidays on record. The prolonged traffic declines weighed on point-of-sale trends, even in our Innerwear products as there were fewer people in the stores. This caused retailers to pull back on their orders, which in turn impacted our shipments for the quarter. The impact was across all channels and relative to our expectations, it was split between our Innerwear and Activewear segments. 
Relative to last year, the lion share of the decline was in Activewear as Innerwear sales were down only 2% in the quarter. As retail traffic improved in the last 2 weeks of December and into January, so did our point-of-sale trends. Looking at January, our basics POS is up low-single digits month-to-date, while Champion and the sporting goods midtier and department channels is up low-double digits. 
While weather affected Q4 and our POS is rebounding from that, our core business in 2015 was essentially flat for the year and I'm not at all satisfied with that level of performance. So we're being proactive by putting in place several focused initiative to drive into revenue growth in 2016 and beyond. And this is something I am committed to deliver. 
Let me take you through why I'm so confident we can achieve our sales guidance for 2016, which calls for growth of 1% on the low end of the range and 3% on the high end. To reach a low end of our range, we only need about $70 million of incremental sales, which we should be able to hit with the $50 million from acquisition contributions and the absence of last year's $50 million to $60 million of Innerwear headwinds from the retail inventory destocking and our intimates brand transition, partially offset by approximately $40 million in currency headwinds. From there, the execution of our various sales initiatives as well as a more normalized Q4 represents another $100 million to $150 million in revenue opportunity that could put us at/or above the high end of our range. 
There are sports-specific sales initiatives that I have the organization focused on delivering. One, continue to drive Innovate-to-Elevate by expanding space of our successful innovation platform such as X-Temp. 2, apply Innovate-to-Elevate to our core products by driving innovation and making the right investments to deliver better volume growth. 3, continue to accelerate growth online and build upon our leading market share positions across all of our brands. And 4, deliver product enhancements in Champion across all channels. 
With my focus on reenergizing sales growth, I want to emphasize that these efforts and investments will to come with the same focus on profitability and cash flow generation. And you can see that in our guidance, which calls for roughly 100 basis points of operating margin expansion driven by our acquisition synergies as well as our continued focus on effectively managing our SG&A. 
We also intend to deliver a record level of cash flow this year. Rick will walk you through the various drivers of our cash flow, but let me talk to the largest contributor, inventory. 
To bring our inventory levels down in a cost-efficient manner, we will need to make small adjustments our manufacturing production schedule, which will do by taking a little time out, internalizing additional production and by drawing down our raw materials a work in process. 
So in closing, our brand is strong, our innovation is working, we're expanding our margins and we're generating significant synergies from acquisitions. Add to this a heavy focus on how exiting our sales initiatives and I feel really good about our ability to deliver another year of double-digit earnings growth in 2016. 
I'll now turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerald. Last quarter, I spoke about how we create strong shareholder returns through the combination of our core business strategies or acquisition strategies and our cash deployment strategies. This is the underlying formula that drives the magni
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerald. Last quarter, I spoke about how we create strong shareholder returns through the combination of our core business strategies or acquisition strategies and our cash deployment strategies. This is the underlying formula that drives the magnification of our growth rate from sales to operating profit and, again, to earnings per share. 
2015 was the third year in a row we've delivered on magnifying our growth rate down the P&L and we believe we're able to -- we believe we're well positioned to do it again in 2016. 
Before I turn to the results, I'd like to point everyone to our FAQ document, which provides additional details on our 2015 results as well as our 2016 guidance. 
For 2015, the 8% increase in revenue was driven by acquisitions as our core business ended flat with the sales decline in Q4. Operating profit increased 13% or nearly $100 million due to the addition of roughly $15 million from acquisitions and a 150 basis point increase in our core operating margin as we benefited from efficiency gains in our supply chain, synergies from acquisitions and ongoing cost controls. 
Earnings per share grew 17%, driven by the growth in operating profit and slightly lower tax rate and the contribution from share repurchases. And cash flow from operations was $227 million. The weaker than expected cash flow was the result of an inventory buildup due to the sales shortfall coming very late in the year. With no markdown risk and specific action plans to reduce inventory, we believe the impact was temporary. 
Turning to our 2016 guidance. We expect full-year sales to be $5.8 billion to $5.9 billion, which represents a 1% to 3% increase over last year. And as Gerald highlighted, we have a variety of focused initiatives that give us confidence in our ability to deliver on our revenue target. We expect operating profit to be $920 million to $950 million, which implies 90 to 110 basis point increase in our operating profit margin and includes roughly $40 million of acquisition synergies. 
Our EPS guidance of $1.85 to $1.91 represents 11% to 15% growth over last year and includes the following assumptions. Interest and other expense is expected to be $115 million to $120 million. Our tax rate is expected to be 10% to 11%. And in terms of share repurchases, we expect to spend a similar amount to last year. 
Finally, we expect cash flow from operations to be approximately $750 million to $850 million. Using the midpoint of our guidance ranges, this represents an increase of roughly $575 million from last year, which is being driven by 4 main factors. First, more than $300 million from improved working capital driven by reduced inventory. Second, roughly $140 million from the lower expected cash charges absent any new acquisitions. Third, roughly $60 million from expected growth and adjusted net income. And fourth, a $60 million reduction in our pension contribution. 
With over $300 million of cash in our balance sheet at year end, our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of about 2.3x as well as our expected cash generation in 2016, we are extremely well positioned to continue to execute on our capital allocation strategy. And our strategy is simple: Use our cash flow to fund capital investments in our dividend, use debt for acquisitions and use excess free cash flow to buy back stock. 
So in summary, we generated significant shareholder value over the past several years and with our focus on driving sales growth along with our continued execution on expanding our margins, we are well positioned to deliver another year of double-digit EPS growth. Add to that about $800 million in expected cash flow as well as upside from potential acquisitions and we feel really good about 2016. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to T.C.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Eric Tracy from Brean Capital.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, and I guess, Gerald, for you, if I could just that a little bit different on the 4Q revs, both from an environment and consumer perspective, walk us through a little bit more how you discern between weather versus just outright weaker traffic or som
componenttext: Rich, and I guess, Gerald, for you, if I could just that a little bit different on the 4Q revs, both from an environment and consumer perspective, walk us through a little bit more how you discern between weather versus just outright weaker traffic or something more structural going on that gives you comfort that we should expect the acceleration into '16.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me talk on that but Q4 and then I'll also let Gerald talk about the initiatives going into '16. You go back to October, it was cold, things are looking really good. November, December came, it was the third warmest November and December since
componenttext: Yes. So let me talk on that but Q4 and then I'll also let Gerald talk about the initiatives going into '16. You go back to October, it was cold, things are looking really good. November, December came, it was the third warmest November and December since 1895. And December was actually a warmest. And you could actually see the correlation as temperature got above normal, retail traffic was dropped and then we saw an impact in our POS. So I think a lot of it was clearly impacted by that. How much is overall consumer spending, you can't really tell. But clearly, I think it was a very unusual holiday period. That said, you expect it to be in our cold-weather activewear areas. It was. That was down about 12% in the quarter, but it was so strong and actually impacted Innerwear, which when you take out the 53rd week, was actually down 2% in the quarter. The good thing is we started to see it rebound in December going into January. And I'll turn it over to Gerald to talk a little bit more about initiatives to drive results in '16.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we look forward, we really have a focus set of initiatives that we've built on proven tactics to better drive consistent top line over time. And really, it focuses in 2 areas. First, we're going to keep doing what's working and that, clearly, is Inn
componenttext: So as we look forward, we really have a focus set of initiatives that we've built on proven tactics to better drive consistent top line over time. And really, it focuses in 2 areas. First, we're going to keep doing what's working and that, clearly, is Innovate-to-Elevate is working. Our innovation platforms like X-Temp and our elevated product in Champion are all driving sales increases and we're gaining additional space that we have going in place for 2016. There are 2 areas where we refine our strategy a bit. 1 is in the area of accelerating our growth online. The online channel continues to grow very rapidly and apparel now, 18% of apparel sales are online. We're well-positioned there. Our brand sold leading shares already and our sales, while there are 7% of our sales are down online today, they're also calling in a double-digit rate. So we actually one of our largest customers now are it like a customer at a large peer player that sales online is going 70% -- approximately 70% rate. So we're going to invest more resources to grow this business faster, both people, we're dedicating more people and resources as well as marketing investments to maximize our position in this channel. Secondly, we're rebalancing our focus a bit on driving our core volume. And really in 2 areas. If you look at our core business, we've stayed behind our core innovation such as TAGLESS for a number of years and our underwear business for example. And it's time to drive new innovation there. So you'll see innovation coming across our core basics business late in '16 and into '17. And secondly, you'll see us rebalancing our media to focus more balanced approach both the core and our innovation platforms over time. We think these are good strategies that take the best of what we're doing and moderately refines our strategy against basics and gives us confidence that we're well positioned to deliver on our guidance for 2016.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, my follow-up would be just in terms of the cash flow. You've got working cap go down pretty significantly. Just walk through the inventory draw down, the potential for sort of downtime within manufacturing, how should that impact. And th
componenttext: And then I guess, my follow-up would be just in terms of the cash flow. You've got working cap go down pretty significantly. Just walk through the inventory draw down, the potential for sort of downtime within manufacturing, how should that impact. And then ultimately, on the stepup cash flow for next year, Rich, maybe just, again, highlight the acquisition environment and the pipeline of things that you guys are potentially looking at.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start with the inventory drawdown first. Of course, let me just say, first of all, that our inventory levels are high but the quality is good, as Rick noted. And so we have good quality, but we'd like to see those levels lower and we'll take
componenttext: Well, let me start with the inventory drawdown first. Of course, let me just say, first of all, that our inventory levels are high but the quality is good, as Rick noted. And so we have good quality, but we'd like to see those levels lower and we'll take actions to draw that down through the year and we'll do that through a few ways. First, we always look at where we can and as for us cutting off outsource production. And second, as we will take 1 week or so of timeout in our internal production. And finally, we will draw down our work in process and raw materials and Rick referred to some of that. Last year, we had built up some of that for the internalization of DBApparel and we'll continue to draw that down over the years as people out at our inventories back in line.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, let me just say this. We've been through the inventory with a fine toothed comb, so we can say with high degree of confidence, there's no markdown risk here. We're confident on that. There will be some costs earlier in the year associated with these
componenttext: Eric, let me just say this. We've been through the inventory with a fine toothed comb, so we can say with high degree of confidence, there's no markdown risk here. We're confident on that. There will be some costs earlier in the year associated with these actions that Gerald's talked about. We've built that into our guidance.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think there was a third was in there, then you went from inventory all the way to acquisitions, but I'll go ahead and discuss that. Acquisitions is just working with for us. There's no ifs and buts, we're doing well with Maidenform, we're still seein
componenttext: So I think there was a third was in there, then you went from inventory all the way to acquisitions, but I'll go ahead and discuss that. Acquisitions is just working with for us. There's no ifs and buts, we're doing well with Maidenform, we're still seeing a little bit of the last synergies and 2016. Knights Apparel and Hanes Europe are working extremely well, both beat their plans in 2015. We're in full swing to reap acquisition synergy benefits and so we feel really good about it. And we've now got the bandwidth to start looking for our next set of acquisitions and it's part of our strategy and will be part of our strategy and I feel really good about where we are.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tough quarter. Can you talk about -- did you guys see anything at the retail level in terms of the sell through in the Innerwear category. It's one of the lower numbers you posted even when you back out all the non-comparable items and FX and acquisitions
componenttext: Tough quarter. Can you talk about -- did you guys see anything at the retail level in terms of the sell through in the Innerwear category. It's one of the lower numbers you posted even when you back out all the non-comparable items and FX and acquisitions in between the intimates category versus the basics, men's versus women's, is there anything you can glean there to help understand what's going on? Or is it really just such a broad base kind of across-the-board slowdown in the right revenue line?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you back out the 53rd week, the Innerwear category in general was down about 2% year-on-year. And clearly, it was tied to the falloff in traffic. And we saw it fall off late in December as traffic caught up with those replenishment tren
componenttext: Well, I think when you back out the 53rd week, the Innerwear category in general was down about 2% year-on-year. And clearly, it was tied to the falloff in traffic. And we saw it fall off late in December as traffic caught up with those replenishment trends. I think from the standpoint of looking forward, we saw that POS begin to rebuild as traffic built late in the holiday and into January. We've seen our basics POS, for example, rise into low single digits. But I would say that as you look through the day that we can see that in the broad business, for example, we came up a strong third quarter. Our fourth quarter, when you back out the 53rd week, that business was actually flat in the quarter in spite of the traffic. So it gives us very strong confidence in our brand consolidation strategy and certainly, optimistic it will drive that forward. And Omar, let me talk about channel a little bit because this was really -- broad-based. We saw across all channels of trade. I will say, however, it was probably a little bit more concentrated in midtier and department stores, which if you just think of what they're offering is, is probably going to be a little bit more weather driven than some of the math. But it was pretty strong -- pretty darn strong across the board, the impact of traffic declines.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does Gerald comment around element? Is that saying something about the basics and the men's side of it? And maybe the Innovate-to-Elevate there is a little bit longitude and ready for some new stuff to come in or are you comfortable where you're at?

componenttext: No. I think it's just the opposite. If you remember the first half of the year, we're struggling a little bit in intimates because we're going through the brand transition. We said a lot of that was behind us at the sort of late summer. You saw a really good strong third quarter results and then browse in particular when you back out the 53rd week, we actually had good strong momentum and Gerald actually think it was up slightly in the quarter when you back out the 53rd week. So I think just tactically, we're just better setup we are because of some of the things that happened earlier in the year. I wouldn't read into it negatively about basics.

componenttext: Sure. We expect about $40 million in synergies for the year. The bulk of it will be coming from Knights Apparel and our program in DBA in Knights Apparel. And it will be a little bit backend loaded, more or even towards SG&A. As is often the case, the initial flow of synergies comes more in SG&A than the cost of sales synergies come later.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And just want to follow up on the Activewear category, maybe just digging a little bit deeper. So it sounds that you guys feel like it's pretty much weather issues out there. I guess, investors have been trying to kind of figure out, is this
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And just want to follow up on the Activewear category, maybe just digging a little bit deeper. So it sounds that you guys feel like it's pretty much weather issues out there. I guess, investors have been trying to kind of figure out, is this category flowing just given a lot of excess that we've seen out there across the number of brands, maybe if you could talk about how you feel about the category in general going forward this year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We still feel bullish about the category. Certainly, the Champion brand ended up mid-single digits and the Sports Specialty in the midtier and department store channels. For the year, it was running well above that through Q3 and then it fell off as the w
componenttext: We still feel bullish about the category. Certainly, the Champion brand ended up mid-single digits and the Sports Specialty in the midtier and department store channels. For the year, it was running well above that through Q3 and then it fell off as the weather-related pressures hit our replenishment in that business. But as we look forward in our bookings and so forth in this spring, we're very optimistic about where that business is going, expect it to be in the 10% plus growth range. And there's early signs of recovery in the POS and the mass channel as well. So we're very optimistic about the category going forward.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how you're thinking about acquisition. What types of acquisition are you looking at? What regions and what categories would you want to enter?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I know you're pretty familiar with our 4 criteria, but for those that might be, I'll just quickly restate them. Obviously, in our core categories, complementary revenue growth opportunities, justifiable on the synergies, mainly supply chain but also
componenttext: Yes. I know you're pretty familiar with our 4 criteria, but for those that might be, I'll just quickly restate them. Obviously, in our core categories, complementary revenue growth opportunities, justifiable on the synergies, mainly supply chain but also as SG&A and quickly accretive. After that, we don't have necessarily a prioritization. Anything that falls through that screen would be a viable candidate. So it would either be Innerwear or Activewear, both domestic and international. And I think over time, you'll see us have opportunities along all of those dimensions, both Innerwear, Activewear, domestic and international. In terms of the near term, we're always talking people in working on things and as soon as we get a deal signed, we'll let you all know.

componenttext: Okay. As a follow-up, could you talk a little bit about e-commerce and how you're thinking about the e-commerce part of your business as it develops. Given the challenges we're seeing at retail and from a traffic standpoint from an underlying sales standpoint.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just give you a couple of big picture things and I'll turn it over to Gerald to talk about some more of the specifics and reiterate some of his comments from earlier. When you talk about Q4 and you talk about online, I think a lot of people ha
componenttext: Yes. Let me just give you a couple of big picture things and I'll turn it over to Gerald to talk about some more of the specifics and reiterate some of his comments from earlier. When you talk about Q4 and you talk about online, I think a lot of people have also asked, is some of the retail traffic declines driven by channel shift from bricks and mortar, retailers to online. How they will stop for everyone? And in fact, some of our large Internet pure play businesses, the growth rates, while they were still strong, were cut by 2/3 in the fourth quarter. So everybody was feeling the impacts of a soft holiday. So while that shift may be going on, I think we just need to keep that in perspective. But online here, it's growing, it's growing with our traditional retailers. It's growing through our own efforts and we're also working with pure plays. And so it clearly needs to be a big area of focus. And Gerald, do you want to highlight a couple of specific things that you're doing?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, first of all, we're really well positioned, our brands are well positioned in the channel. And we're working very carefully with across bricks and mortars as well as pure plays in our own sides to drive the business across all those channels
componenttext: Yes, I think, first of all, we're really well positioned, our brands are well positioned in the channel. And we're working very carefully with across bricks and mortars as well as pure plays in our own sides to drive the business across all those channels, leveraging our position, our brands and our marketing investments. And as I referenced, certainly, with the major pure player, we've seen significant growth and we expect our overall growth as we work across all these prayers to grow at a double-digit rate going forward to really drive our business.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jay Sole for Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jay Sole for Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So question on the operating margin guidance for 2016. I think in the FAQ documents has the midpoint of the 2016 guidance applies 100 basis point increase in operating profit margin with more coming from SG&A and gross margin. Can you talk about within gr
componenttext: So question on the operating margin guidance for 2016. I think in the FAQ documents has the midpoint of the 2016 guidance applies 100 basis point increase in operating profit margin with more coming from SG&A and gross margin. Can you talk about within gross margin, obviously, oil should be benefits, maybe FX and some major currencies should be a help. It sounds like you went off inventory reductions, but is there any other offsets there? It's sounds like the inventories were relatively clean, so you're not kind of anticipating big markdowns. Can you talk about some of the more levers and drivers of growth margins in 2016?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think you're going to see a lot of the same sorts of things that you seen in the past. You've got manufacturing cost savings that will flow through. And again, some of -- that will be offset somewhat by the cost associated with the inventory reduc
componenttext: Sure. I think you're going to see a lot of the same sorts of things that you seen in the past. You've got manufacturing cost savings that will flow through. And again, some of -- that will be offset somewhat by the cost associated with the inventory reduction. And so we think that the operating -- the gross profit margin improvement this year will be more modest than what we've seen in recent years. But really, the recent years have been distorted a little bit by things like DBA's P&L structure, which has much higher gross profit margins and much higher SG&A. That's now kind of the flow -- we've now seen that flow through our P&L and it's now part of who we are. So let's -- so we think basically the same drivers, just a little more modest growth than what we've seen.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to say that -- and thank you for focusing on the operating margin improvement first. Because I just think that is just a fabulous result. And while it may come a little differently spread in 2016 than it has historically, our business model co
componenttext: I just want to say that -- and thank you for focusing on the operating margin improvement first. Because I just think that is just a fabulous result. And while it may come a little differently spread in 2016 than it has historically, our business model continues to perform extremely well and we're thrilled with that kind of margin improvement.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: 500 points of operating profit margin improvements since 2012 is not bad.
componenttext: 500 points of operating profit margin improvements since 2012 is not bad.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You can tell that, probably.
componenttext: You can tell that, probably.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Definitely. 100 basis point improvement in this environment is terrific. Maybe just to follow up on that. Can you talk about react quickly to changes, say, in the R&D and different aspects of the cost structure that could allow you to maybe go back and find some savings there?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of our exposure to R&D, we -- one of the benefits of making the vast majority of what we sell is not nearly as dependent on the R&D as a lot of apparel companies resource heavily from that part of the wold. And so to be honest with you, it'
componenttext: Well, in terms of our exposure to R&D, we -- one of the benefits of making the vast majority of what we sell is not nearly as dependent on the R&D as a lot of apparel companies resource heavily from that part of the wold. And so to be honest with you, it's really not that big of a driver, plus we do what we do source from China, we do in U.S. dollars. So it has less of an impact on us than on a lot of other apparel companies.

componenttext: I think your question is about the POS trends. We have seen common -- as the traffic lifted coming through the holiday weekend in January, we did see a positive lift in POS. And that's what we see today. It's early days, but it certainly favorable and falls to the fact.

componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. And then any additional detail, some of the FAQ document, the acquisition in Japan related to the Champion brand. Either way, I guess, what market share present in Asia?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in Japan, we have a licensee for a long period of time. We actually did some of the Champion sales ourselves, but it was with the licensee and we started working with them to actually reacquire the rights and it was actually the deal was done last
componenttext: Yes, so in Japan, we have a licensee for a long period of time. We actually did some of the Champion sales ourselves, but it was with the licensee and we started working with them to actually reacquire the rights and it was actually the deal was done last year and it actually starts to flow into 2016. It's relatively small. It's good size for that market. We feel really good about it. I think, in total, that business, Joe, are going to be close to $100 million, I think, in '16. So we feel good about them continuing to drive Hanes and Champion in that market. We have right for Champion throughout the Americas and Asia and where we can start to use that plugging into the design in the products that we do for the U.S. and continue to expand into Japan. We've got a business down in Australia that's also leveraging that same product line. And so that's our plan, to continue to drive growth in Champion not only domestically but internationally as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the amount of volatility we're dealing with versus our earnings models across the sector right now, can I just ask you to give a little better sense of the cadence of the year on the top line and the operating margin and the guidance you gave, maybe
componenttext: Given the amount of volatility we're dealing with versus our earnings models across the sector right now, can I just ask you to give a little better sense of the cadence of the year on the top line and the operating margin and the guidance you gave, maybe just a little bit of help on what we should be thinking about in the first quarter to get us off in the right to the start of the year here.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. A couple things. If you recall from our comments that's probably picked up, Knights Apparel will be incremental to us in the first quarter and it's about $20 million of sales. We acquired them in April, so that will be anniversary-ed at that point.
componenttext: Sure. A couple things. If you recall from our comments that's probably picked up, Knights Apparel will be incremental to us in the first quarter and it's about $20 million of sales. We acquired them in April, so that will be anniversary-ed at that point. We mentioned the $30 million in Japan. That will come a little later in the year in terms of top line. The synergies, as we mentioned, about $40 million would be mostly in the back half of the year and then the $40 million of FX headwinds, I would expect to be heavily weighted in the first half and a lot in the first quarter, actually. And so -- and then we talked about some possible savings with inventory management and that is going to be, again, heavily weighted in the first half of the year and a lot in the first quarter.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could ask a follow-up. As I look at different revenue scenarios for all the companies in the group here, it's pretty easy to figure out for you guys in particular the incremental margins as revenues come in about plans and since you gu
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could ask a follow-up. As I look at different revenue scenarios for all the companies in the group here, it's pretty easy to figure out for you guys in particular the incremental margins as revenues come in about plans and since you guys are really good at controlling the cost and even a strong macro, but if revenues do come in closer to flat, how should we think about the point of fixed versus floating cost and your ability to deliver on the EPS line of the macro works against us. Any kind of quantitative support you could offer there?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just talk about that conceptually. In the very short term, it's obviously a little harder to overreact. Actually, I was -- given where sales ended up, I was thrilled with the fact that actually our operating margin didn't de-lever in Q4. So I think
componenttext: Let me just talk about that conceptually. In the very short term, it's obviously a little harder to overreact. Actually, I was -- given where sales ended up, I was thrilled with the fact that actually our operating margin didn't de-lever in Q4. So I think our ability to manage it quickly was pretty darn good in that quarter. If it's over a longer period of time, and I'm inferring some of the way you're asking it, if you started to see a much broader base, soft consumer environment, it's going to last, our ability to last is substantially greater. I'd also remind you that in any given quarter, we have a lot of volatility as you've now seen. But in places like Innerwear, over the period of a year or so, those types of things will start to work themselves out. In fact, in both 2008 and 2009, men's underwear had a lot of quarter ended up slightly up in both of those years. But over a period of 1 year or more, our ability to react is pretty high. Right thing about our business is we've got a lot of things that drive profitability. We've got acquisition synergies, we're independent of the consumer environment, we've got strong cash flows that we can use. So we've talked about the pay dividends and buy back stock. We've got other acquisitions to do and I'm very comfortable as Gerld took you through the sales, what we need to just get to the low end of our sales range. A lot of it just acquisition. Rather we've got close the absence of longtime things from '15. And so we feel really good about our '16 numbers to be able to deliver them.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David Glick from Buckingham Research.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Just a follow-up question on this POS trends and that I have a follow-up on e-commerce. I'm assuming that retailers are in the position to order -- to reorder from you from a replenishment perspective based on the POS trends that they're seeing as opposed to kind of tightening their receipt plans. Also you're up against some big destocking in the first quarter, if I recall. So I just want to make sure we can make that logical conclusion that shipment trends are correlating with the POS trends we're seeing at retail.

componenttext: Certainly, from the standpoint of our replenishment Innerwear goods, they will pick up with replenishment as replenishment as POS goes, our replenishment will follow. In the case of cold weather goods, if they haven't been taken at this point, those sales are not going to occur now until next year when you go to the cold weather of next year. But on the replenishment piece of the business and Innerwear in particular and we do see thatx POS pics of the replacement.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously your not counting on this cold weather goods on your plan to be shipped?
componenttext: So obviously your not counting on this cold weather goods on your plan to be shipped?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No.  In fact, let me actually restate and Gerald talked about it. When you look at the low end of our guidance, he exclusively said that we're not assuming in that end any lift from fourth quarter next year. It's basically the same kind of results that yo
componenttext: No.  In fact, let me actually restate and Gerald talked about it. When you look at the low end of our guidance, he exclusively said that we're not assuming in that end any lift from fourth quarter next year. It's basically the same kind of results that you would have seen in 2015. It's not until you start to go to the high end of our range that we start to actually expect that we begin to see Q4 next year start to normalize. That's an important point. Highlighting it.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up on e-commerce. How do you think about investing in your own e-commerce side as a transactional site versus more an information site as opposed to really partnering up with your sort of omnichannel wholesale customer as well, obv
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up on e-commerce. How do you think about investing in your own e-commerce side as a transactional site versus more an information site as opposed to really partnering up with your sort of omnichannel wholesale customer as well, obviously there's the big retailer which you've had a lot of success with Amazon. I mean, how do you look at investing your resources across the various alternatives you have, particularly when it pertains to Amazon and it pertains to your own site.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, in our own site, we really believe is a true convergence now of where the consumer learns and where the consumer shops. And they may come to your site and learn, they may go out and good retail and buy, they may come to your site and l
componenttext: Well, first of all, in our own site, we really believe is a true convergence now of where the consumer learns and where the consumer shops. And they may come to your site and learn, they may go out and good retail and buy, they may come to your site and learn and go to another site and buy. So we view our site is a very important informational source as well as a selling source just as we view our presentation at retails is another way to provide information or representing our brands on Amazon is also another way that consumers go and learned and that they will also go to stores. So it really is a convergence of the consumer across channels from a communication and purchasing.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I'll share with you and I go to be settled of that Gerald and his group put together. And they were tracking where people were doing searches for different products. And actually, when they took the snapshot, 50% of the searches that were being don
componenttext: David, I'll share with you and I go to be settled of that Gerald and his group put together. And they were tracking where people were doing searches for different products. And actually, when they took the snapshot, 50% of the searches that were being done for similar products, it were actually doing well they were in a store. And it shows that everything's now totally interconnected. You could be in a Kohl's or a Wal-Mart or whatever and searching the Internet to find out more information to make a purchase decision. So I think it's going to all blend and merge and we need to be go all of those.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Kernan from Cowen & Company.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to go back to inventory. obviously, pretty significantly here, you talked about minimum markdown risk but there's also a lot of inventory in the channel from other brands across apparel. Can you just walk us through why you're so confident
componenttext: So I just want to go back to inventory. obviously, pretty significantly here, you talked about minimum markdown risk but there's also a lot of inventory in the channel from other brands across apparel. Can you just walk us through why you're so confident there's minimal markdown risk and what the timing looks like in terms of this inventory drawing down.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me break the inventory down in 2 buckets for you. And I think clearly answer your question. In the case of Innerwear, the same inventories used, all year long, so as POS comes back up, then the orders come behind it. And it just continues to shift. In
componenttext: Let me break the inventory down in 2 buckets for you. And I think clearly answer your question. In the case of Innerwear, the same inventories used, all year long, so as POS comes back up, then the orders come behind it. And it just continues to shift. In the case of cold weather goods, ours are fairly basic cold weather goods. So those that did sell yesterday are actually goods that we didn't sell in the current season. We can actually carry over and sell again next year. So we don't have any risk in those as well. It's basically so things like that that will carry over and sell next year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just shift back to the revenue question. The guidance, I think, assumes $50 million in revenue from acquisitions. Can you talked to what you're looking at terms of acquisitions for 2016 geographically, category wise, and the confidenc
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just shift back to the revenue question. The guidance, I think, assumes $50 million in revenue from acquisitions. Can you talked to what you're looking at terms of acquisitions for 2016 geographically, category wise, and the confidence you have in consummating a deal this year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that $50 million that you referred to are acquisitions that are already completed. So it's the simply $20 million ramp of Knights Apparel plus the $30 million additional from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe. Nothing in our guidance has a
componenttext: Yes. So that $50 million that you referred to are acquisitions that are already completed. So it's the simply $20 million ramp of Knights Apparel plus the $30 million additional from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe. Nothing in our guidance has anything about a future acquisition and I think that's important. We're now turning our attention to begin looking at acquisitions in 2016 and beyond. But we don't have anything like that built into our guidance.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually that's incorrect. That was Champion Japan, the $30 million.
componenttext: Actually that's incorrect. That was Champion Japan, the $30 million.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I was thinking of Hanes Europe and Champion Japan. Thank you, Gerald.
componenttext: Thank you. I was thinking of Hanes Europe and Champion Japan. Thank you, Gerald.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on valuation. It seems like there's been a lot of valuation contraction out there certainly in the public market. So our valuations looking more appealing at this point than they were maybe 12 months ago.
componenttext: And then just on valuation. It seems like there's been a lot of valuation contraction out there certainly in the public market. So our valuations looking more appealing at this point than they were maybe 12 months ago.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's fair to say that over time, if you go back and look at our Gear for Sports acquisition and Knights Apparel, fairly similar businesses, and we probably paid about -- turned in a half [ph] higher for Knights Apparel -- for Knights Apparel than
componenttext: I think it's fair to say that over time, if you go back and look at our Gear for Sports acquisition and Knights Apparel, fairly similar businesses, and we probably paid about -- turned in a half [ph] higher for Knights Apparel -- for Knights Apparel than we would have back when we bought Gear for Sports in 2010. How that may change over time remains to be seen. What we're really focused on is what we can do with the acquisition and how much value we can create and we've been thrilled. All  of these acquisitions that we've had, the after-tax cash returns are easily in the teens. And we're convinced there's deals out there that we can do over time to continue to drive great value creation for our shareholders.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ike Boruchow from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ike Boruchow from Wells Fargo.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one. I guess, rich, just real quick. You document the acquisition of Japan. Is there anything that inhibits you from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe. And is that something you would have -- that doesn't treat you, I think, as a smal
componenttext: Just a quick one. I guess, rich, just real quick. You document the acquisition of Japan. Is there anything that inhibits you from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe. And is that something you would have -- that doesn't treat you, I think, as a small business. And then, Gerald, just to go back to that 8th largest customer that you referenced. I'm just curious how that business was works relative to your other brick-and-mortar partners. Meaning, how big do you ultimately think that could grow to, is the profitability different, better, worse? And how does the pricing work there? I'm assuming there's no real difference that would create any disparities. But just curious on color on that whole dynamic.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to talk about any one specific acquisition and nobody should infer that we're focused on any one thing in particular. Obviously, people do know that Champion Europe was a business that was spun out of Sara Lee many, many years ago. And it's
componenttext: I'm not going to talk about any one specific acquisition and nobody should infer that we're focused on any one thing in particular. Obviously, people do know that Champion Europe was a business that was spun out of Sara Lee many, many years ago. And it's obviously a candidate that could one day make sense, yet you need a lot of things to fall into place for 2 people to be able to come together and decide to have a marriage. And so while it's something that's out there, as you said, it's a relatively small business. And it'll continue to be on our list. What we're focused on is there's lots of ways for us to create value with acquisition. There's a lot of different types of companies that fit our 4 criteria. And as we're continuing to work with people and we get a deal done, we'll make sure we announce it.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as the second part of the question, on the online business, as I've said in a minute ago, we go on to business online really 3 ways, brick-and-mortar retails, online strategies for our own sites as well as our pure plays. And generally we work with al
componenttext: And as the second part of the question, on the online business, as I've said in a minute ago, we go on to business online really 3 ways, brick-and-mortar retails, online strategies for our own sites as well as our pure plays. And generally we work with all of them. We bring them ideas in business and sell similar brands and similar structures to all of them in the wholesale model weather they're bricks-and-mortar online or pure plays. And we drive those business accordingly and our goal is to be well represented in all of them and grow across those businesses.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Anna Andreeva from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Anna Andreeva from Oppenheimer.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a follow-up on the gross margin guidance for '16 being a little bit more moderate than historically. Should we expect the opportunity more back half driven, given the sales initiative? And the near term, I guess, inventory overhang. And then seco
componenttext: I guess, a follow-up on the gross margin guidance for '16 being a little bit more moderate than historically. Should we expect the opportunity more back half driven, given the sales initiative? And the near term, I guess, inventory overhang. And then secondly, looking at profitability in direct channel, it came down pretty significantly in the quarter and for the year and we know outlet traffic has been difficult. Are you guys reevaluating your commitment to this channel at all? Is there an opportunity to perhaps close some stores as leases come due?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: With respect to your first question, yes, I think you're going to infer from what we've said that gross margin will be stronger in the second half of the year than in the first as a result of the various pieces we talked about.
componenttext: With respect to your first question, yes, I think you're going to infer from what we've said that gross margin will be stronger in the second half of the year than in the first as a result of the various pieces we talked about.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of DTC, remember, the 53rd week actually impacts that business disproportionately to some of the other segments, right?
componenttext: In terms of DTC, remember, the 53rd week actually impacts that business disproportionately to some of the other segments, right?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was about $8 million in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: It was about $8 million in the fourth quarter?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On sales alone. So when you look at that, you got to factor that in. In terms of more to your strategic question, which is the piece of that, the outlet store business, how do we think of it because of the other piece within there is our direct-to-consume
componenttext: On sales alone. So when you look at that, you got to factor that in. In terms of more to your strategic question, which is the piece of that, the outlet store business, how do we think of it because of the other piece within there is our direct-to-consumer online business such as obviously, with the continued to build and grow that piece. The outlet business for us has always been there. We're in it most of the malls around the country. It's a business for us to be in. It's never going to be a growth driver. In some cases, as rents in some places have gone up, it doesn't make sense for us to be there. And if the lease comes up, we'll go ahead and exit from that particular mall. We look at everything on our 4-wall profitability basis and as long as the thing is making money, we'll continue to keep the store. And if it's not, we'll let it wind down. But on the flip side, I want to reinforce the online piece of that is clearly a growth vehicle.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Joan Payson from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Joan Payson from Barclays.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked a good amount about the online growth going forward, but as we think about 2016 and even beyond that and some of the other channels whether it's mass or department store or sporting goods stores, where do you see the most opportunity or what ar
componenttext: You talked a good amount about the online growth going forward, but as we think about 2016 and even beyond that and some of the other channels whether it's mass or department store or sporting goods stores, where do you see the most opportunity or what are the growth profiles for each of those channels?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'd see opportunity actually in all the channels. We don't view online as the only opportunity. Certainly as we look at sporting goods and so forth, there's still quite a bit of distribution to get with our Champion brand. We've expanded quite a bi
componenttext: Well, we'd see opportunity actually in all the channels. We don't view online as the only opportunity. Certainly as we look at sporting goods and so forth, there's still quite a bit of distribution to get with our Champion brand. We've expanded quite a bit, but we still see a number of doors and a number of segments within those doors that we don't have distributions. So we see substantial opportunity there as the Champion brand. we look across Innerwear, as I mentioned in my prepared comments, we continue to expand our innovation platforms like X-Temp. We feel good that with our intimates brand transition behind us, we've got growth potential there as well. So we're not giving up on any channel. We see significant opportunity across all the channels.

The apparel business in general is fragmented in Europe as the continent itself is fragmented into many countries. And so there's certainly, over time, more opportunities to look across for broader acquisitions as well as build our own and we're very bullish on Europe right now pregnant as a future growth, area of future growth.

componenttext: Sure. I think in terms of 2015, really, the main driver of the cash flow shortfall in 2015, really, was the inventory. When you look at the numbers that almost matched up to the -- to our most recent guidance in 2015 was, the sales shortfall. But we continue to have production at levels that we were just able to react in time because of the sales shortfall coming. So like the year. As for '16, you normally see our cash flow very heavily weighted towards the back end of the year. I think with Gerald and his team on the inventory adjustment programs and the initiatives that they've got, I think you'll see that moderate some. It's not you're still going to see the -- most of the cash flow and the back half of the year. But I don't think you'll see quite as big a peak in '16 as you saw in '15.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would then like to hand the conference over to T.C. Robillard, Chief
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would then like to hand the conference over to T.C. Robillard, Chief Investment -- Chief Investor Relations Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands quarterly investor conference call and webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the fourth quarter of 2015. Hopefully, everyone has had a chance to review the new
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands quarterly investor conference call and webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the fourth quarter of 2015. Hopefully, everyone has had a chance to review the news release we issued earlier today. The news release and the replay of the call can be found in the Investors section of our hanes.com website. 
On the call today, we may make forward-looking statements, either on our prepared remarks or in the associated question-and-answer session. These statements are based on current expectations or beliefs and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. These risks are detailed in our various filings with the SEC and may be found on or website as well as in our news releases. The company does not undertake to update or revise any forward-looking statements, which speak only to the time at which they are made. 
Unless otherwise noted, today's references to our consolidated financial results as well as our 2016 guidance exclude all onetime charges and expenses. Additional information, including a reconciliation of these and other non-GAAP performance measures to GAAP, can be found in today's press release. 
With me on the call today are Rich Noll, our Chief Executive Officer; Gerald Evans, our Chief Operating Officer; and Rick Moss, our Chief Financial Officer. For today's call, Rich will focus on a few big-picture themes, Gerald will focus on key highlights within our business operations and Rick will focus on certain financial aspects of our results. 
I will now turn the call over to Rich.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, T.C. 2015 was another record year for HanesBrands. We grew revenue, 8%; operating profit, 13%; and earnings per share, 17%, once again magnifying our growth rates as you walk down the P&L. And we intend to do it again in 2016. While these are g
componenttext:
Thank you, T.C. 2015 was another record year for HanesBrands. We grew revenue, 8%; operating profit, 13%; and earnings per share, 17%, once again magnifying our growth rates as you walk down the P&L. And we intend to do it again in 2016. While these are great results, make no mistake, they are not up to the high standards to which we hold ourselves at HanesBrands. We did not fully deliver on our Q4 commitments. 
While Q4 was impacted by the well-publicized retail traffic declines, frankly, we struggled a bit on the sales line all last year. So it's time to refine our approach and regain our sales momentum. We have a variety of focused initiatives designed to reenergize sales. These initiatives, which Gerald will highlight, give us confidence in our ability to firmly deliver our 2016 revenue target. 
We also expect another year of double-digit earnings growth, growing EPS 11% to 15%. Importantly, we can achieve the low end of this range just with our expected acquisition synergies, our historical level of SG&A leverage and the projected contribution from share repurchases. 
In terms of cash flow, we have several action plans in place that put us on track to generate up to $850 million this year, which would be the highest level on our history. To put this in perspective, this is the amount of cumulative cash flow we generated in the first 3 years as a public company. 
Turning to acquisitions. Both DBA, now renamed Hanes Europe, and Knights Apparel continued to perform extremely well. Operating results were above plan, the integrations are progressing on schedule and we are on target to deliver $40 million in synergies this year. And as I mentioned last quarter, we have turned our attention to 2016 acquisitions. A number of variables obviously need to fall into place. But with the integration of Knights Apparel and Hanes Europe now in full swing, we have the bandwidth to take on additional acquisitions. 
So in closing, we are refocusing on driving our top line, and we are well positioned for another year of double-digit EPS growth with upside provided by potential future acquisitions. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Gerald.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich. We have a lot of things working very well in our business, such as our innovations, our supply chain efficiencies, our margin-enhancement strategies and our acquisitions. And this is evidenced by 3 consecutive years of double-digit growth in
componenttext:
Thanks, Rich. We have a lot of things working very well in our business, such as our innovations, our supply chain efficiencies, our margin-enhancement strategies and our acquisitions. And this is evidenced by 3 consecutive years of double-digit growth in both operating profit and earnings per share. However, the fourth quarter did not turn out as we had expected. Retail traffic declined in high single-digit rates in November and the first 3 weeks of December, driven by one of the warmest holidays on record. The prolonged traffic decline weighed on point-of-sale trends, even in our Innerwear products as there were fewer people in the stores. This caused retailers to pull back on their orders, which in turn impacted our shipments for the quarter. The impact was across all channels, and relative to our expectations, it was split between our Innerwear and Activewear segments. Relative to last year, the lion share of the decline was in Activewear as Innerwear sales were down only 2% in the quarter. 
As retail traffic improved in the last 2 weeks of December and into January, so did our point-of-sale trends. Looking at January, our basics POS is up low single digits month-to-date, while Champion in the sporting goods, mid-tier and department store channels is up low double digits. 
While weather affected Q4 and our POS is rebounding from that, our core business in 2015 was essentially flat for the year, and I am not at all satisfied with that level of performance. So we're being proactive by putting in place several focused initiatives to drive improved revenue growth in 2016 and beyond, and this is something I am committed to deliver. 
Let me take you through why I'm so confident that we can achieve our sales guidance for 2016, which calls for growth of 1% on the low end of the range and 3% on the high end. To reach the low end of our range, we only need about $70 million of incremental sales, which we should be able to hit with the $50 million from acquisition contributions and the absence of last year's $50 million to $60 million of Innerwear headwinds from the retail inventory destocking and our intimates brand transition, partially offset by approximately $40 million in currency headwinds. From there, the execution of our various sales initiatives as well as a more normalized Q4 represents another $100 million to $150 million in revenue opportunity that could put us at/or above the high end of our range. 
There are 4 specific sales initiatives that I have the organization focused on delivering. One, continue to drive Innovate-to-Elevate by expanding space of our successful innovation platforms such as X-TEMP; two, apply Innovate-to-Elevate to our core products by driving innovation and making the right investments to deliver better volume growth; three, continue to accelerate growth online and build upon our leading market share positions across all of our brands; and four, deliver product enhancements in Champion across all channels. 
With my focus on reenergizing sales growth, I want to emphasize that these efforts and investments will still come with the same focus on profitability and cash flow generation. And you can see that in our guidance, which calls for roughly 100 basis points of operating margin expansion, driven by our acquisition synergies as well as our continued focus on effectively managing our SG&A. 
We also intend to deliver a record level of cash flow this year. Rick will walk you through the various drivers of our cash flow, but let me talk to the largest contributor, inventory. To bring our inventory level down in a cost-efficient manner, we will need to make small adjustments to our manufacturing production schedule, which we'll do by taking a little time-out, internalizing additional production and by drawing down our raw materials and work in process. 
So in closing, our brand is strong. Our innovation is working. We're expanding our margins, and we're generating significant synergies from acquisitions. Add to this the heavy focus I have on exiting our sales initiatives, and I feel really good about our ability to deliver another year of double-digit earnings growth in 2016. 
I'll now turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerald. Last quarter, I spoke about how we create strong shareholder returns through the combination of our core business strategies or acquisition strategies and our cash deployment strategies. This is the underlying formula that drives the magni
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerald. Last quarter, I spoke about how we create strong shareholder returns through the combination of our core business strategies or acquisition strategies and our cash deployment strategies. This is the underlying formula that drives the magnification of our growth rate from sales to operating profit and again to earnings per share. 2015 was the third year in a row we've delivered on magnifying our growth rate down the P&L, and we believe we're able to -- we believe we're well positioned to do it again in 2016. 
Before I turn to the results, I'd like to point everyone to our FAQ document, which provides additional details on our 2015 results as well as our 2016 guidance. For 2015, the 8% increase in revenue was driven by acquisitions as our core business ended flat with the sales decline in Q4. Operating profit increased 13% or nearly $100 million due to the addition of roughly $50 million from acquisitions and a 150 basis point increase in our core operating margin as we benefited from efficiency gains in our supply chain, synergies from acquisitions and ongoing cost controls. 
Earnings per share grew 17%, driven by the growth in operating profit and slightly lower tax rate and the contribution from share repurchases. And cash flow from operations was $227 million. The weaker-than-expected cash flow was the result of an inventory buildup due to the sales shortfall coming very late in the year. With no markdown risk and specific action plans to reduce inventory, we believe the impact was temporary. 
Turning to our 2016 guidance. We expect full year sales to be $5.8 billion to $5.9 billion, which represents a 1% to 3% increase over last year. And as Gerald highlighted, we have a variety of focused initiatives that give us confidence on our ability to deliver on our revenue target. We expect operating profit to be $920 million to $950 million, which implies a 90 to 110 basis point increase in our operating profit margin and includes roughly $40 million of acquisition synergies. 
Our EPS guidance of $1.85 to $1.91 represents 11% to 15% growth over last year and includes the following assumptions: interest and other expense is expected to be $115 million to $120 million. Our tax rate is expected to be 10% to 11%. And in terms of share repurchases, we expect to spend a similar amount to last year. 
Finally, we expect cash flow from operations to be approximately $750 million to $850 million. Using the midpoint of our guidance ranges, this represents an increase of roughly $575 million from last year, which is being driven by 4 main factors; first, more than $300 million from improved working capital, driven by reduced inventory; second, roughly $140 million from a lower expected cash XA charges, absent any new acquisitions; third, roughly $60 million from expected growth in adjusted net income; and fourth, a $60 million reduction in our pension contribution. 
With over $300 million of cash on our balance sheet at year-end, a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of about 2.3x as well as our expected cash generation in 2016, we are extremely well positioned to continue to execute on our capital allocation strategy. And our strategy is simple: use our cash flow to fund capital investments in our dividend, use debt for acquisitions and use excess free cash flow to buy back stock. 
So in summary, we've generated significant shareholder value over the past several years. And with our focus on driving sales growth, along with our continued execution on expanding our margins, we are well positioned to deliver another year of double-digit EPS growth. Add to that about $800 million in expected cash flow as well as upside from potential acquisitions, and we feel really good about 2016. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to T.C.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
