headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Eric Tracy from Brean Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Eric Tracy from Brean Capital.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If -- Rich, and I guess, Gerald, for you, if we could just dig a little bit deeper on the 4Q revs, both from an environment and consumer perspective, walk us through a little bit more -- how you discern between weather versus just outright weaker traffic
componenttext: If -- Rich, and I guess, Gerald, for you, if we could just dig a little bit deeper on the 4Q revs, both from an environment and consumer perspective, walk us through a little bit more -- how you discern between weather versus just outright weaker traffic or something more structural going on that gives you comfort that we should expect that acceleration into '16.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me talk a little bit about Q4, and then I'll also let Gerald talk about the initiatives going into '16. You go back to October, it was cold, things are looking really good. November, December came. It was the third warmest November and Decembe
componenttext: Yes. So let me talk a little bit about Q4, and then I'll also let Gerald talk about the initiatives going into '16. You go back to October, it was cold, things are looking really good. November, December came. It was the third warmest November and December since 1895. And December was actually the warmest, and you could actually see the correlation. As temperature got above normal, retail traffic was dropped, and then we saw it impact our POS. So I think a lot of it was clearly impacted by that. How much is overall consumer spending? You can't really tell. But clearly, I think it was a very unusual holiday period. That said, you expect it to be in our cold-weather Activewear areas. It was. That was down about 12% in the quarter. But it was so strong, it actually impacted Innerwear, which when you take out the 53rd week, was actually down 2% in the quarter. The good thing is we started to see it rebound in December going into January. And I'll turn it over to Gerald to talk a little bit more about initiatives to drive results in '16.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we look forward, we really have a focused set of initiatives that we've built on proven tactics to better drive consistent top line over time, and really it focuses in 2 areas. First, we're going to keep doing what's working, and that clearly is Inn
componenttext: So as we look forward, we really have a focused set of initiatives that we've built on proven tactics to better drive consistent top line over time, and really it focuses in 2 areas. First, we're going to keep doing what's working, and that clearly is Innovate-to-Elevate is working. Our innovation platforms like X-TEMP and our elevated product in Champion are all driving sales increases, and we're gaining additional space that we'll have in -- going in place for 2016. There are 2 areas there where we will refine our strategies a bit. One is in the area of accelerating our growth online. The online channel continues to grow very rapidly, and apparel now, 18% of apparel sales are online. We're well positioned there. Our brands hold leading shares already. And our sales, while there -- 7% of our sales are done online today, they're also growing in a double-digit rate. So we -- and actually one of our largest customers now, our eighth largest customer is a large pure player that sales online is growing at 70% -- approximately 70% rate. So we're going to invest more resources to drive this business faster, both people. We're dedicating more people resources as well as marketing investment to maximize our position in this channel. Secondly, we're rebalancing our focus a bit on driving our core volume and really in 2 areas. If we look at our core business, we've stayed behind our core innovation such as TAGLESS for a number of years in our underwear business, for example. And it's time to drive new innovation there. So you'll see innovation coming across our core basics business late in '16 and into '17. And secondly, you'll see us rebalancing our media to focus more balanced across both the core and our innovation platforms over time. We think these are good strategies that take the best of what we're doing that moderately refines our strategy against basics and gives us confidence that we are well positioned to deliver on our guidance for 2016.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess my follow-up would be just in terms of the cash flow. You've got working cap expected to go down pretty significantly. Just walk through the inventory drawdown, the potential for sort of downtime within manufacturing, how should that impa
componenttext: And then I guess my follow-up would be just in terms of the cash flow. You've got working cap expected to go down pretty significantly. Just walk through the inventory drawdown, the potential for sort of downtime within manufacturing, how should that impact. And then ultimately, on the stepped up cash flow for next year, Rich, maybe just, again, highlight the acquisition environment and the pipeline of things that you guys are potentially looking at.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start with the inventory drawdown, the first portion of it. Let me just say, first of all, that our inventory levels are high, but the quality is good, as Rick noted. And so we have good quality, but we'd like to see those levels lower, and w
componenttext: Well, let me start with the inventory drawdown, the first portion of it. Let me just say, first of all, that our inventory levels are high, but the quality is good, as Rick noted. And so we have good quality, but we'd like to see those levels lower, and we'll take actions to draw that down through the year, and we'll do that through a few ways. First, we always look at where we can is first cutting off the outsource production. And second is we will take a week or so of time-out in our internal production. And finally, we will draw down our work in process in raw materials, and Rick referred to some of that. Last year, we had built up some of that for the internalization of DBApparel, and we'll continue to draw that down over the years as we pull our inventories back in line.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, let me just say this. We've been through the inventory with a fine-toothed comb. So we can say with a high degree of confidence, there's no markdown risk here, very confident of that. There will be some costs earlier in the -- early in the year asso
componenttext: Eric, let me just say this. We've been through the inventory with a fine-toothed comb. So we can say with a high degree of confidence, there's no markdown risk here, very confident of that. There will be some costs earlier in the -- early in the year associated with these actions that Gerald has talked about. We've built that into our guidance.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think there was a third question in there, Eric, then I'll ask -- you went from inventory all the way to acquisitions, but I'll go ahead and discuss that. Acquisitions is working great for us. There is no ifs, ands or buts. We're doing well with Maid
componenttext: So I think there was a third question in there, Eric, then I'll ask -- you went from inventory all the way to acquisitions, but I'll go ahead and discuss that. Acquisitions is working great for us. There is no ifs, ands or buts. We're doing well with Maidenform. We're still seeing a little bit of the last synergies in 2016. Knights Apparel and Hanes Europe are working extremely well. Both beat their plans in 2015. We're in full swing to reap acquisition synergy benefits, and so we feel really good about it. And we've now got the bandwidth to start looking for our next set of acquisitions, and it's part of our strategy and will be part of our strategy and feel really good about where we are.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tough quarter. Can you talk about -- did you guys see anything at the retail level in terms of the sell-through in the Innerwear category. It's one of the lower numbers you posted, even when you back out all the non-comparable items and the FX and the acq
componenttext: Tough quarter. Can you talk about -- did you guys see anything at the retail level in terms of the sell-through in the Innerwear category. It's one of the lower numbers you posted, even when you back out all the non-comparable items and the FX and the acquisitions in between the intimate category versus the basics, men's versus women's. Is there anything you can glean there to help understand what's going? Or is it really just such a broad-base kind of across-the-board slowdown in the revenue line?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you back out the 53rd week, the Innerwear category in general was down about 2% year-on-year. And clearly, it was tied to the falloff in traffic. And we saw it fall off late in December as traffic caught up with those replenishment tren
componenttext: Well, I think when you back out the 53rd week, the Innerwear category in general was down about 2% year-on-year. And clearly, it was tied to the falloff in traffic. And we saw it fall off late in December as traffic caught up with those replenishment trends. I think from the standpoint of looking forward, we saw that POS begin rebuild as traffic built late into the holiday and into January. We've seen our basics POS, for example, rise into low single digits. And I would say that as you look through the data, you can see that in the bra business, for example, we came off a strong third quarter. Our fourth quarter, when you back out the 53rd week, that business was actually flat in the quarter in spite of the traffic. So it gives us very strong confidence in our brand consolidation strategy and certainly optimistic it will drive that forward.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Omar, let me talk about channel a little bit because this was really broad-based. We saw it across all channels of trade. I will say, however, it was probably a little bit more concentrated in mid-tier and department stores, which if you just think of
componenttext: And Omar, let me talk about channel a little bit because this was really broad-based. We saw it across all channels of trade. I will say, however, it was probably a little bit more concentrated in mid-tier and department stores, which if you just think of what they're offering is, it's probably going to be a little bit more weather driven than some of the mass. But it was pretty strong -- excuse me, pretty darn strong across the board, the impact of traffic declines.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does Gerald's comment around intimates, is that saying something about the basics and the men's side of it? And maybe the Innovate-to-Elevate there is a little bit long in the tooth and ready for some new stuff to come in or are you comfortable where you'
componenttext: Does Gerald's comment around intimates, is that saying something about the basics and the men's side of it? And maybe the Innovate-to-Elevate there is a little bit long in the tooth and ready for some new stuff to come in or are you comfortable where you're at?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's just the opposite. If you remember, in the first half of the year, we were struggling a little bit in intimates because we're going through the brand transition. We said a lot of that was behind us at the -- sort of late summer. You saw a
componenttext: No. I think it's just the opposite. If you remember, in the first half of the year, we were struggling a little bit in intimates because we're going through the brand transition. We said a lot of that was behind us at the -- sort of late summer. You saw a really good strong third quarter results. And then in bras, in particular, when you back out the 53rd week, we actually had good strong momentum, and Gerald  actually think it was up slightly in the quarter when you back out the 53rd week. So I think just tactically, we were just better set up there because of some of the things that have happened earlier in the year. I wouldn't read into it negatively about basics.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Susan Anderson from FBR.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Susan Anderson from FBR.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good job in the tough environment. I was wondering if I could follow-up on the DBA acquisition. So it sounds like the integration is pretty much done now. How should we think about the flow through of synergies this year? Is it going to be more back-end l
componenttext: Good job in the tough environment. I was wondering if I could follow-up on the DBA acquisition. So it sounds like the integration is pretty much done now. How should we think about the flow through of synergies this year? Is it going to be more back-end loaded, pretty equal throughout the year? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- we actually said the integration is really now just in full swing. So it's not done. I think we're well on our way. And so you'll start to see synergies build this year going into '17 and even into '18. So there's a lot of tailwinds to come fr
componenttext: Yes. The -- we actually said the integration is really now just in full swing. So it's not done. I think we're well on our way. And so you'll start to see synergies build this year going into '17 and even into '18. So there's a lot of tailwinds to come from that. Specifically about this year, Rick, do you want to talk about the overall synergies?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We expect about $40 million in synergies for the year. The bulk of it will be coming from Knights Apparel and -- or  from DBA and Knights Apparel. And it will be a little bit back-end loaded, more oriented  towards SG&A. This -- as is often the case
componenttext: Sure. We expect about $40 million in synergies for the year. The bulk of it will be coming from Knights Apparel and -- or  from DBA and Knights Apparel. And it will be a little bit back-end loaded, more oriented  towards SG&A. This -- as is often the case, the initial flow of synergies comes more in SG&A, then the cost of sales, synergies come later.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then just want to follow up on the Activewear category, maybe just digging a little bit deeper. So it sounds like you guys feel like it's pretty much weather issues out there. I guess investors have been trying to kind of figure out, is
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then just want to follow up on the Activewear category, maybe just digging a little bit deeper. So it sounds like you guys feel like it's pretty much weather issues out there. I guess investors have been trying to kind of figure out, is this category slowing, just given a lot of excess that we've seen out there across the number of brands. Maybe if you could talk about how you feel about the category in general going forward this year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We still feel bullish about the category. Certainly, the Champion brand ended up mid-single digits in the sports specialty, in the mid-tier and department store channels. For the year, it was running well above that through Q3, and then it fell off a
componenttext: Yes. We still feel bullish about the category. Certainly, the Champion brand ended up mid-single digits in the sports specialty, in the mid-tier and department store channels. For the year, it was running well above that through Q3, and then it fell off as the weather-related pressures hit our replenishment in that business. But as we look forward in our bookings and so forth into spring, we're very optimistic about where that business is going, expect it to be in the 10% plus growth range. And there's early signs of recovery in the POS and the mass channel as well, so we're very optimistic about the category going forward.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Christian Buss from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Christian Buss from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how you're thinking about acquisition. What types of acquisitions are you looking at? What regions and what categories would you want to enter?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how you're thinking about acquisition. What types of acquisitions are you looking at? What regions and what categories would you want to enter?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I know you're pretty familiar with our 4 criteria, but for those that might not be, I'll just quickly restate them. Obviously, in our core categories, complementary revenue growth opportunities, justifiable on the synergies, mainly supply chain but a
componenttext: Yes. I know you're pretty familiar with our 4 criteria, but for those that might not be, I'll just quickly restate them. Obviously, in our core categories, complementary revenue growth opportunities, justifiable on the synergies, mainly supply chain but also SG&A and quickly accretive. After that, we don't have necessarily a prioritization. Anything that falls through that screen would be a viable candidate, so would either be Innerwear or Activewear, both domestic and international. And I think over time, you'll see us have opportunities along all of those dimensions, both Innerwear, Activewear, domestic and international. In terms of the near term, we're always talking to people and working on things. And as soon as we get a deal signed, we'll let you all know.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, could you talk a little bit about e-commerce and how you're thinking about the e-commerce part of your business as it develops, given the challenges we're seeing at retail and from a traffic standpoint from an underlying sell-through stand
componenttext: As a follow-up, could you talk a little bit about e-commerce and how you're thinking about the e-commerce part of your business as it develops, given the challenges we're seeing at retail and from a traffic standpoint from an underlying sell-through standpoint?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just give you some -- a couple of big-picture things, and I'll turn it over to Gerald to talk about some more of the specifics and reiterate some of his comments from earlier. When you talk about Q4 and you talk about online, I think a lot of
componenttext: Yes. Let me just give you some -- a couple of big-picture things, and I'll turn it over to Gerald to talk about some more of the specifics and reiterate some of his comments from earlier. When you talk about Q4 and you talk about online, I think a lot of people have also asked is some of the retail traffic decline is driven by a channel shift from bricks and mortar, retailers to online. Holiday was tough  for everyone. And in fact, some of our large Internet pure-play businesses, the growth rates, while they were still strong, were cut by 2/3 in the fourth quarter. So everybody was feeling the impacts of a soft holiday. So while that shift may be going on, I think we just need to keep that in perspective. But online is here, it's growing. It's growing with our traditional retailers. It's growing through our own efforts, and we're also working with pure plays. And so it clearly needs to be a big area of focus. And Gerald, do you want to highlight a couple of specific things that you're doing?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, first of all, we're really well positioned. Our brands are well positioned in the channel itself, and we're working very carefully with -- across bricks and mortar as well as pure plays in our own sites to drive the business across all those
componenttext: Yes. I think, first of all, we're really well positioned. Our brands are well positioned in the channel itself, and we're working very carefully with -- across bricks and mortar as well as pure plays in our own sites to drive the business across all those channels, leveraging our position, our brands and our marketing investments. And as I referenced, certainly, with a major pure player, we've seen significant growth. And we expect our overall growth as we work across all these players to grow at a double-digit rate going forward to really drive our business.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jay Sole from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jay Sole from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a question on the operating margin guidance for 2016. I think in the FAQ document has the midpoint of the 2016 guidance applies 100 basis point increase in operating profit margin with more coming from SG&A than gross margin. Can you talk about -- with
componenttext: So a question on the operating margin guidance for 2016. I think in the FAQ document has the midpoint of the 2016 guidance applies 100 basis point increase in operating profit margin with more coming from SG&A than gross margin. Can you talk about -- within gross margin, obviously, oil should be benefits. Maybe FX in some of the Asian currency should be a help. It sounds like one offset is the inventory reductions, but is there any other offsets there? It sounds like the inventory is relatively clean, so you're not kind of anticipating big markdowns. Could you just talk about some of the more levers and drivers of gross margin in 2016?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think you're going to see a lot of the same sorts of things that you've seen in the past. You've got manufacturing cost savings that will flow through. And again, some of -- that will be offset somewhat by the cost associated with the inventory re
componenttext: Sure. I think you're going to see a lot of the same sorts of things that you've seen in the past. You've got manufacturing cost savings that will flow through. And again, some of -- that will be offset somewhat by the cost associated with the inventory reduction. And so we think that the operating -- or the gross profit margin improvement this year will be a little more modest than what we've seen in recent years. But remember, the recent years have been distorted a little bit by things like DBA's P&L structure, which has much higher gross profit margins and much higher SG&A. That's now kind of the flow -- we've now seen that flow through our P&L, and it's now a part of who we are. So let's -- so we think basically the same drivers, just a little more modest growth than what we've seen.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I just want to say that -- and thank you for focusing on the operating margin improvement first. Because I just think that is just a fabulous result. And while it may come a little differently spread in 2016 than it has historically, our business
componenttext: Yes. And I just want to say that -- and thank you for focusing on the operating margin improvement first. Because I just think that is just a fabulous result. And while it may come a little differently spread in 2016 than it has historically, our business model continues to perform extremely well, and we are thrilled with that kind of margin improvement.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: 500 basis points of operating profit margin improvement since 2012 is not bad.
componenttext: 500 basis points of operating profit margin improvement since 2012 is not bad.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You can tell we're proud.
componenttext: You can tell we're proud.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Definitely. 100 basis point improvement in this environment is terrific. Just maybe just to follow-up on that. Can you talk about the company's ability to react quickly to changes, say, in the RMB and different aspects of the cost structure that could all
componenttext: Definitely. 100 basis point improvement in this environment is terrific. Just maybe just to follow-up on that. Can you talk about the company's ability to react quickly to changes, say, in the RMB and different aspects of the cost structure that could allow you to maybe go back and find some savings there?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of our exposure to RMB, we -- one of the benefits of making the vast majority of what we sell is not nearly as dependent on the RMB as a lot of apparel companies who source heavily from that part of the world. And so to be honest with you,
componenttext: Well, in terms of our exposure to RMB, we -- one of the benefits of making the vast majority of what we sell is not nearly as dependent on the RMB as a lot of apparel companies who source heavily from that part of the world. And so to be honest with you, it's really not that big of a driver, plus we do our -- what we do source from China, we do in U.S. dollars. So it has less of an impact on us than -- on a lot of other apparel companies.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Taposh Bari from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Taposh Bari from Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: This is Chad Sutherland on for Taposh. First question, just hoping to dig a little deeper on the quarter-to-date commentary. When you talked about basics and Champion both being up, is that relatively broad-based, just any detail you care to provide on that?

componenttext: I think your question is about the POS trends. We have seen come in -- as the traffic lifted come in through the holiday weekend at January, we did see a positive lift in POS. And that's what we've seen today. It's early days, but it's certainly favorable and follows  the traffic.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. And then any additional detail? I saw on the FAQ document, the acquisition in Japan related to the Champion brand. I guess can you talk maybe a little bit about that? And then is it possible to get a breakdown of what other markets -- maybe there are opportunities around Champion either where, I guess what markets you're present in, in Asia?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in Japan, we had a licensee for a long period of time. We actually did some of the Champion sales ourselves, but it was with the licensee. And we started working with them to actually reacquire the rights, and it was -- actually the deal was done
componenttext: Yes. So in Japan, we had a licensee for a long period of time. We actually did some of the Champion sales ourselves, but it was with the licensee. And we started working with them to actually reacquire the rights, and it was -- actually the deal was done last year, and it actually starts to flow into 2016. It's relatively small. It's good size for that market. We feel really good about it. I think, in total, that business, Gerald, won't it be close to $100 million, I think, in 2016? So we feel good about them continuing to drive Hanes and Champion in that market. We have rights for Champion throughout the Americas and Asia and where we can start to use that, plugging into the design in the products that we do for the U.S. and continue to expand in Japan. We've got a business down in Australia that's also leveraging that same product line. And so that's our plan is to continue to drive growth in Champion, not only domestically, but internationally as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the amount of volatility we're dealing with, with our earnings models across the sector right now, can I just help -- ask you to give a little better sense of the cadence of the year on the top line and the operating margin within the guidance you g
componenttext: Given the amount of volatility we're dealing with, with our earnings models across the sector right now, can I just help -- ask you to give a little better sense of the cadence of the year on the top line and the operating margin within the guidance you gave and maybe just a little bit of help on what we should be thinking about in the first quarter to get us off on the right foot to start the year here.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. A couple things. If you recall from our comments that you probably picked up, Knights Apparel will be incremental to us in the first quarter. That's about $20 million of sales. And then we acquired them in April, so they'll be anniversaried at that
componenttext: Sure. A couple things. If you recall from our comments that you probably picked up, Knights Apparel will be incremental to us in the first quarter. That's about $20 million of sales. And then we acquired them in April, so they'll be anniversaried at that point. We mentioned the $30 million in Japan that's -- that will come a little later in the year in terms of top line. The synergies, as we mentioned, are about $40 million will be mostly in the back half of the year. And then the $40 million of FX headwinds, I would expect to be heavily weighted in the first half and a lot in the first quarter, actually. And so -- and then we talked about some costs associated with inventory management, and that's going to be, again, heavily weighted in the first half of the year and a lot in the first quarter.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just ask a follow-up. As I look at different revenue scenarios for all the companies under the -- in the group here, it's pretty easy to figure out for you guys, in particular, the incremental margins if revenues come in above pl
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just ask a follow-up. As I look at different revenue scenarios for all the companies under the -- in the group here, it's pretty easy to figure out for you guys, in particular, the incremental margins if revenues come in above plans since you guys are really good at controlling the cost in even a strong macro. But if the revenues do come in closer to flat, how should we think about the point of fixed versus floating cost and your ability to deliver on the EPS line if the macro works against us? Any kind of quantitative support you could offer there?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just talk about that conceptually. In the very short term, it's obviously a little harder to overreact. Actually, I was -- given where sales ended up, I was thrilled with the fact that actually our operating margin didn't delever in Q4. So I think
componenttext: Let me just talk about that conceptually. In the very short term, it's obviously a little harder to overreact. Actually, I was -- given where sales ended up, I was thrilled with the fact that actually our operating margin didn't delever in Q4. So I think our ability to manage it quickly was pretty darn good in that quarter. If it's over a longer period of time, and I'm inferring some -- the way you're asking it, if you started to see a much broader base, soft consumer environment, it's going to last. Our ability to last is substantially greater. I'd also remind you that in any given quarter, we have a lot of volatilities, as you've now seen. But in places like Innerwear, over the period of a year or so, those types of things will start to work themselves out. In fact, in both 2008 and 2009, men's underwear, while it had a lot of volatile quarter, ended up slightly up in both of those years. But over a period of a year or more, our ability to react is pretty high. The great thing about our business is we've got a lot of things that drive profitability. We've got acquisition synergies. We're independent of that -- the consumer environment. We got strong cash flow that we can use as we've talked about to pay dividends and buy back stock. We've got other acquisitions to do, and I'm very comfortable, as Gerald took you through the sales, what we need to just get to, to the low end of our sales range. A lot of it's just the acquisition wrap that we've got, plus the absence of onetime things from '15. And so we feel really good about our '16 numbers to be able to deliver them.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of David Glick from Buckingham Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David Glick from Buckingham Research.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up question on those POS trends, and then I have a follow-up on e-commerce. I'm assuming that retailers are in a position to order -- to reorder from you from a replenishment perspective based on the POS trends that they're seeing as opposed
componenttext: Just a follow-up question on those POS trends, and then I have a follow-up on e-commerce. I'm assuming that retailers are in a position to order -- to reorder from you from a replenishment perspective based on the POS trends that they're seeing as opposed to kind of tightening their receipt plans. Also you're up against some big destocking in the first quarter, if I recall. So I just want to make sure we can make that logical conclusion that shipment trends are correlating with the POS trends you're seeing at retail.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, from the standpoint of our replenishment Innerwear goods, they will pick up with replenishment as replenishment -- as POS goes, our replenishment will follow. In the case of cold-weather goods, if they haven't been taken at this point, those sa
componenttext: Certainly, from the standpoint of our replenishment Innerwear goods, they will pick up with replenishment as replenishment -- as POS goes, our replenishment will follow. In the case of cold-weather goods, if they haven't been taken at this point, those sales are not going to occur now until next year when you go to the cold weather period of next year. But on the replenishable piece of the business in Innerwear, in particular, you do see that the POS picks up the replenishment.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're not -- you're obviously not counting on those cold-weather goods in your plan to be shipped?
componenttext: So you're not -- you're obviously not counting on those cold-weather goods in your plan to be shipped?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no.
componenttext: No, no.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. In fact, let me actually restate and Gerald talked about it. When you look at the low end of our guidance, he explicitly said that we're not assuming in that end any lift from fourth quarter next year. It's basically the same kind of results that you
componenttext: No. In fact, let me actually restate and Gerald talked about it. When you look at the low end of our guidance, he explicitly said that we're not assuming in that end any lift from fourth quarter next year. It's basically the same kind of results that you would have seen in 2015. It's not until you start to go to the high end of our range that we start to actually expect that we begin to see Q4 next year start to normalize. That's an important point.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for highlighting it.
componenttext: Thanks for highlighting it.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up on e-commerce. I mean, how do you think about investing in your own e-commerce site as a transactional site versus more an informational site as opposed to really partnering up with your sort of omni channel wholesale custo
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up on e-commerce. I mean, how do you think about investing in your own e-commerce site as a transactional site versus more an informational site as opposed to really partnering up with your sort of omni channel wholesale customers as well. Obviously, there's the big e-retailer, which you've had a lot of success with Amazon. I mean, how do you look at investing your resources across the various alternatives you have, particularly when it pertains to Amazon and it pertains to your own site?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, in our own site, what we really believe as a true convergence now of, I think, where the consumer learns and where the consumer shops. And they may come to your site and learn. They may go then -- go to retail and buy. They may come to
componenttext: Well, first of all, in our own site, what we really believe as a true convergence now of, I think, where the consumer learns and where the consumer shops. And they may come to your site and learn. They may go then -- go to retail and buy. They may come to your site and learn and go to another site and buy. So we view our site as a very important informational source as well as a selling source, just as we view our presentation at retail as another way to provide information. Or representing our brands on Amazon is also another way that consumers go and learn, and they may also go to stores. So it truly is a convergence of the consumer across channels from a communication and a purchasing.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. David, I'll share with you an anecdotal piece of data that Gerald and his group put together, and they were tracking where people were doing searches for different products. And actually, when they took this snapshot, 15% of the searches that were be
componenttext: Yes. David, I'll share with you an anecdotal piece of data that Gerald and his group put together, and they were tracking where people were doing searches for different products. And actually, when they took this snapshot, 15% of the searches that were being done for some of our products, people were actually doing while they were in a store. And it shows that everything is now totally interconnected. You could be in a Kohl's or a Wal-Mart or whatever and searching the Internet to find out more information to make a purchase decision. So I think it's going to all blend and merge, and we need to be good at all of those things.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John Kernan from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Kernan from Cowen and Company.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just wanted to go back to the inventory. Obviously, up pretty significantly here. You talked about minimal markdown risk, but there's also a lot of inventory in the channel from other brands across apparel. Can you just walk us through why you're so co
componenttext: So just wanted to go back to the inventory. Obviously, up pretty significantly here. You talked about minimal markdown risk, but there's also a lot of inventory in the channel from other brands across apparel. Can you just walk us through why you're so confident there's minimal markdown risk and what the timing looks like in terms of this inventory drawing down?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me break the inventory down in 2 buckets for you, and I think it'll clearly answer your question. In the case of Innerwear, the same inventory is used all year long. So as POS comes back up, then the orders come behind it, and it just continues t
componenttext: Yes. Let me break the inventory down in 2 buckets for you, and I think it'll clearly answer your question. In the case of Innerwear, the same inventory is used all year long. So as POS comes back up, then the orders come behind it, and it just continues to ship. In the case of cold-weather goods, ours are fairly basic cold-weather goods. So those that didn't sell yesterday are actually goods that we -- didn't sell in the current season. We can actually carry over and sell again next year. So we don't have any risk in those as well. It's basically some things like that, that will carry over and sell next year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can just shift back to the revenue question. The guidance, I think, assumes $50 million in revenue from acquisition. Can you talk to what you're looking at in terms of acquisitions for 2016 geographically, category wise and the confidence y
componenttext: Okay. And if I can just shift back to the revenue question. The guidance, I think, assumes $50 million in revenue from acquisition. Can you talk to what you're looking at in terms of acquisitions for 2016 geographically, category wise and the confidence you have in consummating a deal this year?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the $50 million that you refer to are acquisitions that are already completed. So it's the simply $20 million of wrap of Knights Apparel plus the $30 million additional from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe. Nothing in our guidance says a
componenttext: Yes. So the $50 million that you refer to are acquisitions that are already completed. So it's the simply $20 million of wrap of Knights Apparel plus the $30 million additional from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe. Nothing in our guidance says anything about a future acquisition, and I think that's important. We're now turning our attention to begin looking at acquisitions in 2016 and beyond. But we don't have anything like that built into our guidance.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually just to correct, that was Champion Japan, the $30 million.
componenttext: Actually just to correct, that was Champion Japan, the $30 million.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, thank you. I'm sorry. Did I -- I was thinking of Hanes Europe and Champion Japan. Thank you, Gerald.
componenttext: Oh, thank you. I'm sorry. Did I -- I was thinking of Hanes Europe and Champion Japan. Thank you, Gerald.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on valuation. It seems like there's been a lot of valuation contraction out there certainly in the public market. So are valuations looking more appealing at this point than they were maybe 12 months ago?
componenttext: And then just on valuation. It seems like there's been a lot of valuation contraction out there certainly in the public market. So are valuations looking more appealing at this point than they were maybe 12 months ago?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm -- I think it's fair to say that, over time, if you go back and look at our Gear for Sports acquisition and Knights Apparel, fairly similar businesses, and we probably paid about a -- turn and a half higher for Knights Apparel than we would have back
componenttext: I'm -- I think it's fair to say that, over time, if you go back and look at our Gear for Sports acquisition and Knights Apparel, fairly similar businesses, and we probably paid about a -- turn and a half higher for Knights Apparel than we would have back when we bought Gear for Sports in 2010. How that may change over time remains to be seen. What we really focus on is what we can do with the acquisition and how much value we can create, and we've been thrilled. We've -- all of these acquisitions that we've had, the after-tax cash returns are easily in the teens. And we're convinced there's deals out there that we can do over time to continue to drive great value creation for our shareholders.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ike Boruchow from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ike Boruchow from Wells Fargo.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one. I guess, Rich, just real quick. You're talking about the acquisition of Japan. Is there anything that inhibits you from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe? And is that something that would  -- that does intrigue you? I think it's
componenttext: Just a quick one. I guess, Rich, just real quick. You're talking about the acquisition of Japan. Is there anything that inhibits you from reacquiring the rights to Champion Europe? And is that something that would  -- that does intrigue you? I think it's a small business. And then, Gerald, just to go back to that eighth largest customer that you referenced. I'm just curious how that business works relative to your other brick-and-mortar partners. Meaning, how big do you ultimately think that could grow to? Is the profitability different, better or worse? And how does the pricing work there? I'm assuming there's no real difference that would create any disparities. But just curious some color on that whole dynamic.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm not going to talk about any one specific acquisition, and nobody should infer that we're focused on any one thing in particular. Obviously, people do know that Champion Europe was a business that was spun out of Sara Lee or sold out of Sara Lee m
componenttext: Yes. I'm not going to talk about any one specific acquisition, and nobody should infer that we're focused on any one thing in particular. Obviously, people do know that Champion Europe was a business that was spun out of Sara Lee or sold out of Sara Lee many, many years ago. And it's obviously a candidate that could one day make sense, yet you need a lot of things to fall into place for 2 people to be able to come together and decide to have a marriage. And so while it's something that's out there, as you said, it's a relatively small business. And it will continue to be on our list. What we're focused on is there's lots of ways for us to create value with acquisition. There's a lot of different types of companies that fit our 4 criteria. And as we're continuing to work with people and we get a deal done, we'll make sure we announce it.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as to the second part of the question on the online business. We -- as I've said a minute ago, we go onto business online through really 3 ways, through our brick-and-mortar retailers, we have online strategies; through our own sites as well as throug
componenttext: And as to the second part of the question on the online business. We -- as I've said a minute ago, we go onto business online through really 3 ways, through our brick-and-mortar retailers, we have online strategies; through our own sites as well as through pure plays. And generally we've worked with all of them. We bring ideas in business and sell similar brands and similar structures to all of them in a wholesale model, whether they're bricks-and-mortar online or pure plays. And we drive those businesses accordingly, and our goal is to be well represented in all of them and grow across these businesses.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Anna Andreeva from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Anna Andreeva from Oppenheimer.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a follow-up on the gross margin guidance for '16 being a little bit more moderate than historically. Should we expect the opportunity more back-half driven, given the sales initiative and the near term, I guess, inventory overhang? And then second
componenttext: I guess a follow-up on the gross margin guidance for '16 being a little bit more moderate than historically. Should we expect the opportunity more back-half driven, given the sales initiative and the near term, I guess, inventory overhang? And then secondly, looking at profitability in direct channel, it came down pretty significantly in the quarter and for the year, and we know outlet traffic has been difficult. Are you guys reevaluating your commitment to this channel at all? Is there an opportunity to perhaps close some stores as leases come due?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Anna, with respect to your first question, yes. I think you can infer from what we've said that gross margins will be stronger in the second half of the year than in the first as a result of the various pieces that we've talked about.
componenttext: Yes. Anna, with respect to your first question, yes. I think you can infer from what we've said that gross margins will be stronger in the second half of the year than in the first as a result of the various pieces that we've talked about.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of DTC, we got to remember, the 53rd week actually impacts that business disproportionately to some of the other segments, right?
componenttext: In terms of DTC, we got to remember, the 53rd week actually impacts that business disproportionately to some of the other segments, right?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It was about $8 million in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Right. It was about $8 million in the fourth quarter.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On sales alone. So when you look at that, you got to factor that in. In terms of -- more though to your strategic question, which is the piece of that's the outlet store business, how do we think of it because of the other piece within there is our direct
componenttext: On sales alone. So when you look at that, you got to factor that in. In terms of -- more though to your strategic question, which is the piece of that's the outlet store business, how do we think of it because of the other piece within there is our direct-to-consumer online business, which is obviously want to continue to build and grow that piece. The outlet business for us has always been there. We're in most of the malls around the country. It's a business for us to be in. It's never going to be a growth driver. In some cases, as rents in some places have gone up, it doesn't make sense for us to be there. And if the lease comes up, we'll go ahead and exit from that particular mall. We look at everything on our 4-wall profitability basis. And as long as the thing is making money, we'll continue to keep the store. And if it's not, we'll let it wind down. But on the flip side, I want to reinforce the online piece of that's clearly a growth vehicle.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Joan Payson from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Joan Payson from Barclays.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've talked a good amount about the online growth going forward. But as we think about 2016 and even beyond that and some of the other channels, whether it's mass or department stores or sporting goods stores, where do you see the most opportunity or wh
componenttext: You've talked a good amount about the online growth going forward. But as we think about 2016 and even beyond that and some of the other channels, whether it's mass or department stores or sporting goods stores, where do you see the most opportunity or what are the growth profiles for each of those channels?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'd see opportunity actually in all the channels. We don't view online as the only opportunity. Certainly as we look at sporting goods and so forth, there's still quite a bit of distribution to get with our Champion brand. We've expanded quite a bi
componenttext: Well, we'd see opportunity actually in all the channels. We don't view online as the only opportunity. Certainly as we look at sporting goods and so forth, there's still quite a bit of distribution to get with our Champion brand. We've expanded quite a bit, but we still see a number of doors and a number of segments within those doors that we don't have distributions. So we see substantial opportunity there as well the Champion brand. We look across the Innerwear, as I mentioned in my prepared comments, we continue to expand our innovation platforms like X-TEMP. We feel good that with our intimates brand transition behind us, we've got growth potential there as well. So we're not giving up on any channel. We see significant opportunity across all the channels.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just in 2015, what did X-TEMP and ComfortBlend ultimately represent as a percentage of men's basics and Activewear even? I mean, what could that mix reach in 2016? And are you doing anything differently to get there?
componenttext: And then just in 2015, what did X-TEMP and ComfortBlend ultimately represent as a percentage of men's basics and Activewear even? I mean, what could that mix reach in 2016? And are you doing anything differently to get there?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was roughly 15% in '15, the combined of all those together. And we expect it to grow as we continue to expand space. And that will be balanced some. As we dial up our innovation in the core, you may see that balance out. But there's still ample growth
componenttext: It was roughly 15% in '15, the combined of all those together. And we expect it to grow as we continue to expand space. And that will be balanced some. As we dial up our innovation in the core, you may see that balance out. But there's still ample growth there. And we're taking some of those technologies and then pushing them across other elements, including Champion now as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Kate McShane from Citi Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Kate McShane from Citi Research.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's been speculated that there could be a bankruptcy in the sporting goods arena over the next 6 to 12 months. And I know one of your brands has some exposure to that. How do you incorporate that risk into your guidance? And how do you mitigate some of t
componenttext: It's been speculated that there could be a bankruptcy in the sporting goods arena over the next 6 to 12 months. And I know one of your brands has some exposure to that. How do you incorporate that risk into your guidance? And how do you mitigate some of the inventory risk if that were to happen?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we monitor all of our customers' credit profiles very carefully and gear our relationships with them accordingly. I think the one you're specifically referring to potentially having that issue at some point. We manage our position with them very wel
componenttext: Well, we monitor all of our customers' credit profiles very carefully and gear our relationships with them accordingly. I think the one you're specifically referring to potentially having that issue at some point. We manage our position with them very well. If something like that were to happen, it would really not have a material impact on our financials.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question is unrelated, more to do about the European market. Just wondering now that you've had DBApparel in your ownership for a while, just what you've learned about the European market and what opportunity is there in that mark
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question is unrelated, more to do about the European market. Just wondering now that you've had DBApparel in your ownership for a while, just what you've learned about the European market and what opportunity is there in that market for the rest of your portfolio of brands?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we certainly learned that we made a great acquisition with the one we bought. We have a leadership position in a number of countries, and we have potential to build across a number of countries with a very strong management team to do that f
componenttext: Well, I think we certainly learned that we made a great acquisition with the one we bought. We have a leadership position in a number of countries, and we have potential to build across a number of countries with a very strong management team to do that for us. The apparel business in general is fragmented in Europe as the continent itself is fragmented into many countries. And so there's certainly, over time, more opportunities to look across for broader acquisitions as well as build our own, and we're very bullish on Europe right now as a future growth, our area of future growth.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jim Duffy from Stifel.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jim Duffy from Stifel.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, a couple questions for you on the cash flow. Just eyeballing the spread between your actual cash flow and the initial guidance is more than the increase in inventory on a year-to-year basis, were there other surprise factors that worked against the
componenttext: Rick, a couple questions for you on the cash flow. Just eyeballing the spread between your actual cash flow and the initial guidance is more than the increase in inventory on a year-to-year basis, were there other surprise factors that worked against the cash flow during the year? And then looking out to 2016, I'm curious the seasonality of the cash flow for the year. Can you pull some of that earlier in the year? Or help me think through that on a quarterly basis.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think in terms of the -- of 2015, really, the main driver of the cash flow shortfall in 2015 really was the inventory. When you look at the numbers that almost matched up to the -- to what our most recent guidance in 2015 was the -- that sales sho
componenttext: Sure. I think in terms of the -- of 2015, really, the main driver of the cash flow shortfall in 2015 really was the inventory. When you look at the numbers that almost matched up to the -- to what our most recent guidance in 2015 was the -- that sales shortfall. But we continue to have production at levels, and we weren't just able to react in time because of the sales shortfall coming so late in the year. As for '16, you normally see our cash flow very heavily weighted towards the back end of the year. I think with Gerald and his team on the inventory adjustment programs and initiatives that they've got, I think you'll see that moderate some. It's not -- you're still going to see the -- most of the cash flow in the back half of the year. But I don't think you'll see quite as big a peak in '16 as you saw in '15.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Well, we're always looking at what the economic trade-offs are in refinancing versus leaving them out there. headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the meeting over to T. C. Robillard, Chief Inves
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the meeting over to T. C. Robillard, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the first quarter of 2016. Hopefully, everyone has had a chance review the news re
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the first quarter of 2016. Hopefully, everyone has had a chance review the news release we issued earlier today. The news release, updated FAQ document and the replay of this call can be found in the Investors section of our hanes.com website. 
On the call today, we may make forward-looking statements, either in our prepared remarks or in the associated question-and-answer session. These statements are based on current expectations or beliefs and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. These risks are detailed in our various filings with the SEC and may be found in our website as well as in our news releases. The company does not undertake to update or revise any forward-looking statements, which speak only to the time at which they are made. Unless otherwise noted, today's references to our consolidated financial results as well as our 2016 guidance exclude all onetime charges and expenses. Additional information, including a reconciliation of these and other non-GAAP performance measures to GAAP, can be found in today's press release. 
With me on the call today are Rich Noll, our Chief Executive Officer; Gerald Evans, our Chief Operating Officer; and Rick Moss, our Chief Financial Officer. For today's call, Rich, Gerald and Rick will provide some brief remarks, and then we will open it up to your questions. 
I will now turn the call over to Rich.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, T.C. HanesBrands delivered strong first quarter results, as revenue increased 1%, operating profit increased 10% and earnings per share increased 18%. Our ability to consistently magnify our growth rates as you walk down the P&L demonstrates th
componenttext:
Thank you, T.C. HanesBrands delivered strong first quarter results, as revenue increased 1%, operating profit increased 10% and earnings per share increased 18%. Our ability to consistently magnify our growth rates as you walk down the P&L demonstrates that our strategy to create long-term shareholder value are working. We're driving innovation in our categories, we're generating efficiencies within our supply chain, we're announcing our margins and we're effectively allocating our capital. 
Within the first 100 days of 2016, we increased our dividend 10%, repurchased $380 million of stock and announced the acquisition of Champion Europe. Overall, the year is unfolding as we expected. Point-of-sale trends have rebounded from their severely negative levels in Q4. Our acquisition synergies are ramping on schedule, and our initiatives to reenergize sales growth are on track. All of this gives us confidence in our ability to achieve our 2016 guidance. Add to this our continued focus on executing our long-term strategies, and we believe we are well positioned to deliver double-digit EPS growth for many years to come.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Gerald.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich. We delivered solid results for the first quarter, but more importantly, we made significant progress on our sales initiatives, our inventory actions and our integrations.So let me speak to these in order. Starting with our sales initiative
componenttext:
Thanks, Rich. We delivered solid results for the first quarter, but more importantly, we made significant progress on our sales initiatives, our inventory actions and our integrations.
So let me speak to these in order. Starting with our sales initiatives. If you recall last quarter, I walked you through several initiatives that I had the organization focused on delivering. One of the initiatives is to expand the space of our successful Innovate-to-Elevate platforms. For 2016, we secured new space for various X-TEMP products in the mass and mid-tier channels. 
A second initiative is to ensure we are focusing on our core products with the right balance of promotion, media and innovation. During the first quarter, we began rebalancing our marketing features to drive our core, and the initial sell-through results were positive. As we look to the second half, we're on track to launch our next big innovation directly into our core. 
And the third initiative is to drive online growth. As the migration to online accelerates, we are reallocating our personnel and marketing resources to capture this consumer shift. In the first quarter, our U.S. online sales across all channels increased 15% over last year and now represent 8% of our domestic sales.
I feel really good about the progress we have made. While these initiatives are not expected to fully impact sales growth until the second half of the year, our progress to date gives us confidence in our ability to deliver on our 1% to 3% revenue growth guidance for the year.
Turning to our inventory reduction actions. Recall that the bulk of these actions are expected to come in the first half, while the reduction in our inventory level is expected to begin in the third quarter and continue through the end of the year. During the first quarter, we took time out within our manufacturing network, we lowered the use of external sourcing and we reduced raw material purchases. We expect to complete essentially all of these actions in the second quarter. We're on track to reduce our inventory as planned, and this gives us confidence in our ability to deliver our cash flow guidance for the year. 
Next, I'd like to provide an update on our acquisition integrations. Beginning with Hanes Europe. We're making great progress on our synergies and remain on track to deliver EUR 100 million of annual operating profit by the end of 2018.
The insourcing of production continues to ramp up, and we've begun reducing SG&A, as 120 people exited our operations in France at the end of the quarter. We've completed nearly 8,000 action items and are about 2/3 of the way through the integration.
Touching briefly on their business. Hanes Europe had a solid quarter, delivering operating profit that was slightly ahead of plan. The European price increases are now in place, and we're on track to generate substantial profit growth this year as synergies ramp.
Turning to Knights Apparel. We have completed essentially all of the integration actions and are on track to double their operating profit by 2018. 
With respect to our Champion Japan acquisition, this integration is complete, and we now generate roughly $140 million in sales in Japan between our Champion and Hanes product lines. 
Lastly, we have begun our initial integration planning for Champion Europe. We're excited about the significant revenue growth opportunity for the Champion brand, and we are on track for mid-year close.
Overall, our integrations are progressing on or ahead of schedule, which not only gives us confidence in our ability to deliver $40 million of synergy benefits this year, but also provides us with the bandwidth to do additional acquisitions. 
So in summary, our strategies are working, our acquisition synergies are ramping on schedule, we're progressing on our initiatives to reenergize sales growth and we're on track to reduce our inventory levels, all of which gives us confidence in our ability to drive low single-digit sales growth and double-digit EPS growth in 2016 and beyond. 
I'll now turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerald. We delivered another record first quarter. The combination of our margin enhancement strategies, our acquisition strategies and our capital allocation strategies drove an 18% increase in our earnings per share, once again highlighting the
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerald. We delivered another record first quarter. The combination of our margin enhancement strategies, our acquisition strategies and our capital allocation strategies drove an 18% increase in our earnings per share, once again highlighting the power of our business model to deliver strong returns for our shareholders.
Now let me give you some color on the quarter. Sales increased 1% over last year, driven by the contribution from Knights Apparel and the 1% growth in our Innerwear segment, which was partially offset by $12 million of currency headwinds. As expected, our gross profit margin declined from last year. Efficiency gains from the supply chain were more than offset by the recognition of certain inventory reduction costs, which resulted in a 20 basis point decline in our margin. Our costs were close to $20 million of inventory-related costs this year, $8 million of which hit our P&L in the first quarter, with the majority of the remaining costs expected to come in the second quarter.
SG&A costs in the quarter declined approximately 130 basis points to 25.8% of sales. Key drivers of this improvement were synergies from acquisitions, planned catalog circulation reductions and tight cost controls. This resulted in a 110 basis point increase in our operating profit margin to 12.1%.
Our earnings per share of $0.26 was an increase of 18% over last year. The $0.04 improvement includes $0.01 from operational performance, $0.01 from the 2015 share repurchases and $0.02 of expense timing between the first and second quarters. 
And lastly, our cash flow from operations was a use of $285 million, roughly in line with our expectations.
Turning to guidance. We reiterated our full 2016 guidance, which does not yet include the impact from Champion Europe. Looking at the key components, we expect sales of $5.8 billion to $5.9 billion, which represents a 1% to 3% increase over last year. We expect operating profit to be $920 million to $950 million, which, at the mid-point, implies a 100 basis point increase in our operating profit margin.
We expect EPS of $1.85 to $1.91, which represents 11% to 15% growth over last year. And we expect cash flow from operations to be $750 million to $850 million. 
So in closing, we're off to a great start in 2016, and we're well positioned to deliver on our guidance. Looking forward, as we execute on our proven long-term strategies, we believe we're well positioned to continue to deliver strong shareholder returns for many years to come. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to T.C..

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I think it's really playing out like we expected. We've seen POS pick up, as Rich referred to, coming out of the down period of the fourth quarter. We've seen nice, positive pickup in POS going into the first quarter. And you see that in our Innerwear sales that are up 1%. And it just feels like it's tracking about like we expected. We've begun to implement our sales actions, and while the bulk of those is really expected impact the latter half of the year, the early steps we took on our -- to refocus on the core have been very positive, seeing good results as well. So we feel good about our ability to deliver on our guidance.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess my follow-up would be a little bit bigger picture. But how do you guys thinking about managing through this channel evolution? I know you believe that the consumer is channel-agnostic. But as online, be it your own and/or third party omni-chan
componenttext: And I guess my follow-up would be a little bit bigger picture. But how do you guys thinking about managing through this channel evolution? I know you believe that the consumer is channel-agnostic. But as online, be it your own and/or third party omni-channel continues to develop. In terms of the infrastructure that you have in place, what sort of resources you need to reallocate to ensure that, that business continues to take the direct share that it should?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The apparel sales are clearly shifting online, and online's growing very fast for total apparel sales. And we are really focused on that as well. We grew our sales 15% in the quarter, and we're now about 8% of our domestic sales. Our online, we're sh
componenttext: Yes. The apparel sales are clearly shifting online, and online's growing very fast for total apparel sales. And we are really focused on that as well. We grew our sales 15% in the quarter, and we're now about 8% of our domestic sales. Our online, we're shifting resources, both people and marketing resources, to go after that opportunity. We hold leading shares in our categories online already. But we are now seeing those shares grow. In fact, back in a large pure player, our share is actually as large in our core categories is it is in our brick-and-mortar channel. So we see it at as the place that's growing. We're focused on that. It really is just the reflection of our focus on omnipresence. We want to be where the consumer wants to shop, and increasingly, that's online, and that's where we'll go.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me just start with saying that, overall, the business was up 3%. In the quarter, the sports license apparel business performed particularly well, both the gear business, and we did have the ramp of the Knights Apparel acquisition in the quarter.
componenttext: Sure. Let me just start with saying that, overall, the business was up 3%. In the quarter, the sports license apparel business performed particularly well, both the gear business, and we did have the ramp of the Knights Apparel acquisition in the quarter. Underneath that, to dig a little deeper, the Champion business did experience in sports and department stores experienced the headwind of The Sports Authority bankruptcy in the quarter. Now while it's not particularly big to the total company's only about 0.5% of sales. It's a big customer within that mix. And so that business overall was flat for the quarter. When you peel that back, the rest of the business was actually up nicely double-digit rate. So the core business is sound, just a little bit of headwind there from the TSA perspective. The POS in that business is up double digits as well in the core business. So we see nice fundamentals there. That Champion at mass business is -- we are in the final changes every doing that product. It's beginning to flow in now, continues through the second half and really projected that returning to mid-single-digit growth, in the second half of the year. So when you look at all that together, we're optimistic about it as we turned the corner on that business that we'll see nice positive growth to the year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
