headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the floor over to T.C. Robillard, Chief Inves
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the HanesBrands Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to hand the floor over to T.C. Robillard, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the second quarter of 2016. Hopefully, everyone has had a chance review the news
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the HanesBrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the second quarter of 2016. 
Hopefully, everyone has had a chance review the news release we issued earlier today. The news release, updated FAQ document and a replay of this call can be found in the Investors section of our hanes.com website. 
On the call today, we may make forward-looking statements either in our prepared remarks or in the associated question-and-answer session. These statements are based on current expectations or beliefs and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. These risks are detailed in our various filings with the SEC and may be found on our website as well as in our news releases. The company does not undertake to update or revise any forward-looking statements, which speak only to the time at which they are made. 
Unless otherwise noted, today's references to our consolidated financial results as well as our 2016 guidance exclude all onetime charges and expenses. Additional information, including a reconciliation of these and other non-GAAP performance measures to GAAP, can be found in today's press release. 
With me on the call today are Rich Noll, our Executive Chairman and outgoing CEO; Gerald Evans, our CEO-elect; and Rick Moss, our Chief Financial Officer. For today's call, Rich, Gerald and Rick will provide some brief remarks, and then we will open it up to your questions. 
I will now turn the call over to Rich.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, T.C. This is my 40th and last earnings call. It has been quite a ride. I'd like to take this opportunity to reflect back a little but also to frame our future. Over the last 10 years, we've had 3 distinct phases: the first to transform our su
componenttext:
Thank you, T.C. This is my 40th and last earnings call. It has been quite a ride. I'd like to take this opportunity to reflect back a little but also to frame our future. 
Over the last 10 years, we've had 3 distinct phases: the first to transform our supply chain and cost structure to make us competitive globally; the second, to drive Innovate-to-Elevate to expand our operating margins; and the third, grafting both of these strategies onto acquisitions. 
Over that time, we've built a strong business model that creates value by nurturing world-class brands, delivering innovation to a broad base of consumers, driving volume through our highly efficient global supply chain and effectively deploying our cash flow.
The results have been great for all stakeholders. Over this decade, we have increased revenue from $4 billion to nearly $7 billion, allowing us to expand our employment base from 50,000 to 70,000 people. We have completed 8 acquisitions, mainly internationally, with international sales now close to 1/3 of the business. But we paid attention to more than just expanding the business. We have won numerous awards for our community support, our environmental efforts and have also been recognized as a great place to work. All of this superb effort can be seen in our financial results. We increased operating profit from $400 million to over $1 billion, growing earnings per share from $0.37 to over $2, a 20% compound annual growth rate for the decade, and generated more than $4 billion in cash flow from operations.
But what's even more exciting is our future, as these proven strategies have significant scale and are repeatable. At our current profit run rate, we should be able to generate the next $4 billion of cash flow in less than half the time, which positions us extremely well to continue to annually generate solid double-digit shareholder returns and when you combine this with our experienced management team and the breadth of talent within our organization. That's why I truly believe that for HanesBrands, the best is yet to come.
Before I go, let me add that the last 10 years has been an amazing journey and one that I am deeply proud to have taken with all of you and all of the HanesBrands employees around the world. I had the pleasure of working with this management team for the past decade and, in case of Gerald, over 25 years. Under Gerald's leadership, we created a low-cost, global supply chain, the strength in our world-class brands with Innovate-to-Elevate and seamlessly integrated several acquisitions. The company is in great hands, and I look forward to seeing the next phase unfold as Gerald and the organization takes the business to new heights.
And with that, I am pleased to turn things over to our CEO-elect, who will talk about delivering on our fourth consecutive year of double-digit EPS growth. Gerald?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich. On behalf of all the employees at HanesBrands, we greatly appreciate your leadership over the past decade. And we look forward to continuing to drive our strategies and deliver superior returns to our shareholders. On a personal note, I've t
componenttext:
Thanks, Rich. On behalf of all the employees at HanesBrands, we greatly appreciate your leadership over the past decade. And we look forward to continuing to drive our strategies and deliver superior returns to our shareholders. On a personal note, I've thoroughly enjoyed our working relationship over the past 25 years, and I wish you nothing but the best.
Coming into the year, we knew we were facing a tough comparison in the second quarter due to X-TEMP and Champion pipes that drove last year's mid-single digit growth in basics and 42% growth in Champion in the sports specialty and department store channels, and we planned for it. Year-to-date, our results are right where we expected them to be in terms of sales, operating profit, earnings per share and cash flow from operations. More importantly, we reiterated our guidance for the full year, which, at their midpoints, calls for 8% growth in revenue, 11% growth in operating profit, 16% growth in EPS and $800 million in cash flow from operations.
As we look to the back half of the year, we believe we are very well positioned to achieve our guidance as our key initiatives are unfolding as expected. While there are many initiatives driving our confidence in delivering on the second half, let me highlight 4 specific examples. First, our inventory reduction actions are complete and delivering their intended results, adjusting for the addition of Champion Europe, our inventory decline from the first quarter's level, which in turn helped drive the strong cash flow performance in the quarter. We expect our inventory, excluding Champion Europe and Pacific Brands, to continue to decline through the second half of the year, and we're firmly on track to achieve our cash flow guidance.
Second, the initiative that I laid out at the beginning of the year to drive volume growth in our core Innerwear business is gaining traction. For the quarter, we grew market share in men's underwear, women's panties and socks. Moreover, our focus on the core initiative positions us well for the second half. We have targeted promotions in place for both back-to-school and holiday. We're also set to begin advertising behind our new innovation, Fresh IQ.
Fresh IQ is an odor control technology that mechanically attacks bacteria. This is a great innovation that, we believe, has the potential to impact the overall apparel category. In fact, we've seen some of our highest advertising testing ever with this new product, and the reception by our retailers has been strong. The benefits of Fresh IQ span both Innerwear and Activewear and is now in the market men's underwear, socks and certain Champion products. 
Third, the integrations of Hanes Europe and Knights Apparel are tracking to plan, which puts us on schedule to deliver $40 million in synergies this year. 
And the fourth example driving our confidence in delivering on the second half is that we closed our 2 most recent acquisitions: Champion Europe and Pacific Brands. 
Touching briefly on these acquisitions, we're extremely excited about the addition of these great businesses. Not only do they provide us with strong management teams, but they also provide a nice balance between mid- to high single-digit revenue growth and margin expansion opportunity through synergies. Both management teams have already been to our headquarters, and we are well underway in developing our detailed integration plans. 
So in summary, we are confident in our outlook for the second half. Our results year-to-date are right in line with our plan, and our key initiatives for the second half are unfolding as expected. Looking beyond this year, our goal is to continue to drive our successful setup strategies and leverage our strong business model, which we believe positions us to deliver, on average, mid-single digit revenue growth and double-digit earnings per share growth for many years to come. 
I'll now turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerald. While our second quarter results declined over last year, our Q2 plan called for a decline due to the tough comparisons in basics and Champion as well as quarterly timing shifts in shipments. Year-to-date, our results are right in line wit
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerald. While our second quarter results declined over last year, our Q2 plan called for a decline due to the tough comparisons in basics and Champion as well as quarterly timing shifts in shipments. Year-to-date, our results are right in line with our expectations for sales, operating profit, earnings per share and cash flow.
We reiterated our guidance for the full year, and this was driven by 3 factors: one, the challenges in the overall retail environment were already reflected on our guidance when it was initially set back in February; two, our year-to-date results were in line with our plan; and three, we're confident in our ability to deliver on the second half, as our sales initiatives have traction and are ramping, our acquisitions are generating synergies and our inventory reduction actions are working.
Now let me speak to our performance during the quarter. Beginning with our Innerwear segment. The sequential sales growth in the quarter was right in line with historical trends. And for quarter, the sales performance mirrored the broader retail environment, with a soft April and May giving way to a stronger June. In fact, our Innerwear sales were up 10% in the month of June, with strength continuing into July. Margins in the quarter were strong with segment operating margins of 24.2%. 
Turning to Activewear. The sales decline was driven by our Hanes Activewear business, as our U.S. Champion business was flat when compared to last year. 
Looking at Champion by channel. We saw mid-single digit revenue growth in mass and mid-teens growth in the college bookstore channel. This was offset by declines in the sporting goods mid-tier and department store channels, which were impacted by bankruptcies and a tough comparison as we had a significant concentration of shipments in last year's second quarter.
With respect to profitability, Activewear's operating margins held above 15%, as SG&A controls helped to partially offset the volume decline. 
Switching to international. Sales in the quarter increased by 2%, driven by strength in Europe and Asia. Operating profit increased 14%, while operating margins expanded 90 basis points. Hanes Europe delivered another solid quarter, with sales up 1%, driven by hosiery in France and bras in Spain, while operating margins improved 350 basis points to nearly 9%. We expect continued strong performance in our international business in the second half due to Hanes Europe synergies, momentum in Asia as well as the addition of Champion Europe and Pacific Brands.
Looking at our overall results for the quarter. The decline in both our gross and operating margins was due almost exclusively to the roughly $12 million and expected costs associated with our inventory-related actions. Absent these costs, our margins would have been up slightly over last year despite the expected decline in sales as we benefited from acquisition synergies and SG&A leverage.
Interest and other expense, excluding the one-time costs associated with our refinancing actions, increased nearly $8 million due to increased debt balances, $6 million of which, or $0.01 per share in the quarter, was due to our decision to prefund our recent acquisitions. 
Given the current interest rate environment, the need to fund recent acquisitions and higher rate notes that were callable, we proactively took the opportunity during the quarter to optimize our capital structure. We lowered our overall interest rate and increase the amount of fixed rate debt on our balance sheet. Roughly 2/3 of our debt is now fixed, and we have a blended interest rate of approximately 3.6%.
Tax rate was roughly 6% during the quarter. For the first half, our tax rate was roughly 8%, which is in line with our full year guidance of a high single-digit tax rate. Earnings per share in the quarter was $0.51.
If you recall from last quarter, I highlighted that the decline in our accounts payable balance was a precursor to the expected improvements in both our inventory and our cash flow, and that's exactly what we saw during the second quarter. Our inventory, excluding the $51 million from Champion Europe, declined from the first quarter's level. And this, along with improvements in accounts payable, helped drive $156 million in cash flow from operations, a record for any second quarter in our history.
Now turning to our guidance. We reiterated our full year outlook, which, at their midpoints, implies 8% growth in revenue, 11% growth in operating profit, 16% growth in EPS and $800 million in cash flow from operations. We made small adjustments to our full year estimates for CapEx and acquisition and integration charges now that we've closed the acquisitions and have begun our detailed integration plans. 
Looking at the integration of both Champion Europe and Pacific Brands. We're confident that the total charges for both acquisitions combined should be substantially below earlier acquisitions. As we've become more efficient at integration, we're able to leverage our prior foundational investments, and these integrations are less complex. We estimate the total cost to acquire and integrate both of these acquisitions to be less than $100 million, of which a little more than $50 million are expected to be recognized this year. 
With respect to these 2 acquisitions, we gave you their expected full year contributions in late May. So now let me give you the specific guidance for the quarters because it's very different due to the timing of when we closed Pac Brands and their seasonality.
About $200 million, or approximately 55% of the sales from Champion Europe and Pacific Brands, are expected to be in the fourth quarter. For total HBI, that means third quarter sales should be slightly greater than the fourth quarter, as the impact from these acquisitions temper some of our normal sales cadence. However, from a profit perspective, virtually the entire $0.04 EPS increase from late May shows up in the fourth quarter, leaving the total company's EPS for Q3 between 57 -- $0.55 and $0.57 and, for Q4, between $0.57 and $0.61.
So in closing, our overall results are tracking to plan, our inventory actions are working, our integrations are on schedule, our core sales initiatives are gaining traction and we launched our new innovation, Fresh IQ. All of this gives us confidence in our ability to deliver on our guidance for the year. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to T.C.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: So, Rich, for you, as you sort of pass the baton onto Gerald here, maybe provide a little bit bigger picture perspective on which you see not only the model as its transforms, the world in which you're operating. Obviously, you had some challenges around the revenue line over the last year. What gives you confidence not only in the back half guidance to reaccelerate but kind of longer term, that the brand at the core is still not only relevant but very strong?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to say things that you've heard me say over the last decade. We're in great categories because people use our products every single day of their lives. They've been using them for centuries, and they're going to use them centuries from now. And
componenttext: I'm going to say things that you've heard me say over the last decade. We're in great categories because people use our products every single day of their lives. They've been using them for centuries, and they're going to use them centuries from now. And as long as we do a couple of things, I think it's the secret to success, and that is we need to make sure our cost structures competitive globally. We need to give innovation that we can give to our broad audience, which means we need to nurture strong brands. And if we can do that successfully, we generate a lot of cash and then we can deploy that cash, whatever the environment, to create a lot of value. Right now, it makes a lot of sense to graft those strategies on the acquisitions. That's been working for well over a decade, and that's going to continue to work many decades into the future. And that's what gives me confidence about this thing power of this company. I've said this before, I said it in 2009 in March when everything looked like it was -- the world was going to end. We've been in business for over 100 years and will be in business 100 years from now. In terms of the specifics, Gerald, ilk turn it over to you to talk about the strategies and what you might change going forward.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When I look at the stretches, look, we got a model, which Rich just touched on, that's really working well. We're generating strong on average, sort of mid-single digit growth in the revenue line and double-digit EPS. So here's an awful lot to like a
componenttext: Yes. When I look at the stretches, look, we got a model, which Rich just touched on, that's really working well. We're generating strong on average, sort of mid-single digit growth in the revenue line and double-digit EPS. So here's an awful lot to like about that strategy going forward. Where we do see opportunity is certainly we have a consumer whose increasingly engaging with our brands to learn about our brands and also buy our brands online and will consistently -- going to put more and more effort against going where that consumer's going, both people and resources. And we're seeing the results over we're going to work that even higher but we are starting to integrate [indiscernible] over the last 10 years. I think the second part of your question was about our confidence in guidance for the balance of the year. Let me just say that as we look at that, we see that, first and foremost, our first half results were right in line with our expectations. And second, our low and already assumed a challenging consumer environment as that's played out through the year. And then the third is we have a number of key initiatives in mind, and they're unfolding exactly as we expected them to unfold as we execute them. As we focused and our core initiatives, we saw some initial share gains and Q2 and now we've got promotions in place. We and our core basics for back-to-school and holiday and that with our Fresh IQ initiative, our innovation coming as well. We feel great about the momentum we are carrying into the second half of the year there. As you heard Rick there, inventory reduction actions are working. The inventory's coming down, and we've got those actions behind us. And we're looking forward to more cash flow in the months and quarters ahead. Our Hanes Europe and apparel integrations continue to do extremely well, and we're on target to deliver those synergies. And then finally, we closed on Champion Europe and Pacific Brands that gives us both sales and revenue and profit momentum in the second half. So things are going exactly as we planned, and we feel very comfortable in reaffirming our guidance for the year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as you -- just a follow-up on that. In terms of the inventory, it did sequentially improve, but maybe a little bit more elevated than what we had thought. Maybe it's according to your plan. But as we think that moving through the year, what shoul
componenttext: And then as you -- just a follow-up on that. In terms of the inventory, it did sequentially improve, but maybe a little bit more elevated than what we had thought. Maybe it's according to your plan. But as we think that moving through the year, what should the cadence of that look like? I'm assuming decelerates pretty meaningful to drive that free cash flow in the back half. But we know there's been concerns about the restructuring charges around the acquisition, how that perhaps translates to operating cash flow. Maybe just Rick or Gerald or Richard, whoever wants to chime in on that kind of dynamic and how we should do that cadence in the back half?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I will just point out that we were -- cash flow from operations are $100 million favorable to last year. That same time on a year-to-date basis, so we're in good shape on that front. Let me talk about inventory for just a second. The couple of
componenttext: Sure. Well, I will just point out that we were -- cash flow from operations are $100 million favorable to last year. That same time on a year-to-date basis, so we're in good shape on that front. Let me talk about inventory for just a second. The couple of ways to look at it as you pointed out, Eric, the inventory levels, absent Champion Europe, were actually down from Q2 to Q1. That's unusual. Normally, we build inventory for back-to-school. I think that shows our management inventory management processes are working. Another way to look at it, though, is to look at that at the Bill, the build is about $70 million less in the first half of this year than it was last year. So we're doing a lot to manage this inventory, and it's showing up in our cash flow. We talked about XA charges, and they're going to be significantly lower this year than they were last year. And that's obviously going to be a positive driver for cash flow from operations as well. So I look at all the factors, including improved profitability, I would not forget that in terms of driving cash flow as well. Look at all the key drivers of cash flow, they're all working just as we expected them to so I'm feeling really good about that $800 million.

componenttext: This is Paulie on the line for Christian. Can you speak a little bit about kind of the rollout of this new Fresh IQ product? What we can see in terms of merchandising? And any expectations for kind of being able to gain shelf space with your retail partners?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Fresh IQ is an odor control technology that mechanically attacks bacteria. With it is a technology we're rolling at right now. It began the rollout in this quarter -- in the third quarter and we'll continue to do so through the balance of the year.
componenttext: Sure. Fresh IQ is an odor control technology that mechanically attacks bacteria. With it is a technology we're rolling at right now. It began the rollout in this quarter -- in the third quarter and we'll continue to do so through the balance of the year. Is really one of our -- we've gotten some of the strongest response from consumers we've seen in some time from a purchase attempt standpoint. And it'll roll out across our men's basics, underwear and socks as well as a number of our Champion items. It's going to be available across all of our men's underwear and socks. So it's really rolling across both our core as well as our innovation platforms such as [indiscernible], ComfortBlend. It's similar to what we did a decade ago or so with our tagless tee. The retailers are very excited about this, and you'll see both some shelf expansion, but you'll also see the significant promotion activity behind it as we roll late to the third quarter and into the holiday period, and we'll also begin our media support in the fall as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Congrats, Rich, on your retirement. You've done an amazing job over the past 10 years and will definitely be missed. And then congrats, Gerald, on the new role. I don't know if you can go over maybe just kind of your thoughts around the back half in terms of the Innerwear and Activewear categories and how you see the core businesses, excluding the acquisition growing in the back half.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me start with the Innerwear category. Well, what I would say is, right now, it's in the first half of their, it's really performed as expected. It was up nicely in Q1, up over 1 percentage point in Q1. And we had expected it to be down and shipme
componenttext: Yes. Let me start with the Innerwear category. Well, what I would say is, right now, it's in the first half of their, it's really performed as expected. It was up nicely in Q1, up over 1 percentage point in Q1. And we had expected it to be down and shipments in Q2 as we overlapped the pretty substantial space gains that we experienced in our basics business and X-TEMP last year. As we look to the balance of the year and we execute our initiatives behind our focus on the core initiative as well as we're seeing sequentially improving trends in our bra business, we feel good that we'll have very positive momentum, along with now our new innovation in Fresh IQ and the Innerwear business as we look to the second half. As I turn to the Activewear business, we were down in Q2, but again, it's expected after coming off of a strong first quarter, where we're up 2.8% in first quarter. In the Q2, Hanes Activewear was a key driver of our decline for the quarter as We had some space adjustments to some of our key customers. In Champion, we did bear the brunt of overlapping big pipes in Q2 of last year as well as we did have some headwinds from bankruptcies in the sports specialty. But they were -- Champion overall was flat because we saw mid-single digit results in our mass business and double-digit growth within our college bookstore business. And our Champion POS and sports specialty, in spite of the challenges with bankruptcies, was actually up a quite a bit in the quarter double-digit basis. So overall, we expect Activewear to return to growth as we put the Hanes Activewear adjustments in Q2 behind us. And we continue to see momentum in the business going forward. What I do -- would say, too, is on a global basis, the Champion brand had solid quarter and grew nicely in the quarter, with particular strength in Japan. As we look at Champion on a global basis in the second half, we expect that growth to continue to accelerate. And then addition of Champion Europe will just further accelerate growth on top of that.

componenttext: Sure. I'd be happy to. The bra business actually did show positive growth within the quarter, as we overlapped our brand consolidation business. It was up mid-single digits within the quarter. So we see positive trend in that business. As we look to the balance of the year and we continue to see the power of our brand consolidation, we do believe there'll be positive trend in the second half of that business as well. We see growth in 2 places, certainly, in our -- some of our key brands such as [indiscernible], we see solid growth. But also, as you alluded to, very much we're seeing growth in that ComfortFlex Fit model, which is the blending of the active and the casual, the [indiscernible] leisure, if you will, the bras coming together. And the Hanes business, in particular, is doing very well in that segment.

componenttext: Well, cotton always -- is a little bit volatile, and it'll trade within the range. We don't necessarily believe that the pricing, which is cotton today is something that's going to be around forever. But we -- this is the beauty of our dollar cost averaging approach, the hedging cotton. We're hedged out through essentially through the middle of next year, P&L basis, at the prices were -- at mid-60-ish type range. So we'll fitting. Good about that. And we'll see where it goes. It's -- again, it's hard to predict.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is on the increase in the pretax acquisition and integration charges of $20 million. Can you just explain how the Champion Europe and Pacific Brands deal is closing sooner to drive higher purchase accounting adjustments?
componenttext: Okay. Second question is on the increase in the pretax acquisition and integration charges of $20 million. Can you just explain how the Champion Europe and Pacific Brands deal is closing sooner to drive higher purchase accounting adjustments?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it really wasn't the timing of it. It would -- what generally happens in once we actually acquire the company, we're able to get inside their books a little bit, and we're able to do the very complex purchase accounting processes that we have to go
componenttext: Well, it really wasn't the timing of it. It would -- what generally happens in once we actually acquire the company, we're able to get inside their books a little bit, and we're able to do the very complex purchase accounting processes that we have to go through under GAAP. And those are sometimes, from the outside, a little hard to adjust or to assess. After we got in, we found that they were about roughly $20 million higher than we originally thought I'll point out though, Jay, it's all noncash, it's all just accounting stuff so not cash at all. So while it was up $20 million, it was all noncash items.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich and Gerald, congratulations to both. I have a couple quick question. The first one, I wanted to see, Rich or Gerald, how about some of the challengers just going on in the category and apparel generally, but I don't think Innerwear that on the basic
componenttext: Rich and Gerald, congratulations to both. I have a couple quick question. The first one, I wanted to see, Rich or Gerald, how about some of the challengers just going on in the category and apparel generally, but I don't think Innerwear that on the basic category [indiscernible] immune to it. A lot of traffic moving online. And the basket size is given your price points maybe doesn't fit quite as well, given shipping costs and things like that. Can you kind of dive in on what you're thinking with Amazon and hanes.com and Walmart.com and Target.com and some of the key kind of e-commerce channels and how you're thinking about positioning of your business out a few years and your brand out a few years as this kind of consumer behavior shift continues or even accelerates the basics and in every category? What's your thoughts on that?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We certainly have seen a shift in the consumer's mind to learn and engage with brands from attorney standpoint as well as buying increasing online. And our categories and have seen some of those same shifts, whether they're basics or certainly the ac
componenttext: Yes. We certainly have seen a shift in the consumer's mind to learn and engage with brands from attorney standpoint as well as buying increasing online. And our categories and have seen some of those same shifts, whether they're basics or certainly the active we are business or the intimates business for that matter. And we have been pretty clear for a while that we're going to invest the resources, both people and dollars, to make sure that we get full advantage of that. Within the U.S., for example. We soft again, in mid-teens growth in our online business during the quarter. And in Europe, we also see a number of those markets are highly developed from an online standpoint. We're organizing equally strongly to go after that business and drive those businesses as well. And as we've stated before, our shares online, we have leading shares. They're not as fully developed as they are in a brick-and-mortar and we continue to work to drive those and we're going to do that really by working across all the elements of that online channel, which would include working with our bricks-and-mortar very closely and helping drive their businesses. And they understand that our learning in our brands are important avenue to the people to their site. Certainly, we could continue to develop our own sites, not only as a selling location, but as a communication location of our brand positionings and what our brands have to offer. And then certainly, from the standpoint of working with the major pure plays, we've got a significant amount of effort against that, and we're seeing very strong results as we look at that. Overall, in the U.S., our business is now 8% online and is continuing to grow. And we've got a lot of focus on that going forward.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the shipping issue, shipping cost issue at basket sizes, just wondering how you think about or seeing that having that effect on the e-commerce business.
componenttext: And on the shipping issue, shipping cost issue at basket sizes, just wondering how you think about or seeing that having that effect on the e-commerce business.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- not really. We see similar economics from the standpoint of, for us, shipping our online customers relative to our wholesale customers. From the standpoint of the online, the emergence of free freight and certain levels and things like, it's a certa
componenttext: We -- not really. We see similar economics from the standpoint of, for us, shipping our online customers relative to our wholesale customers. From the standpoint of the online, the emergence of free freight and certain levels and things like, it's a certainly generated even more and more sales of even basics online as the bar for consumers to get the some level of free postage has gotten lower and lower. Some of our [indiscernible] I'll just bet [indiscernible] early ones were such as intimates that reached that bar earlier.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Got you. One quick follow-up on Fresh IQ. If I look back some of your big successful innovations in the past, I mean, the things that really stand out is so simple, so obvious to customer why this is a better product, whether it's [indiscernible]
componenttext: Got you. Got you. One quick follow-up on Fresh IQ. If I look back some of your big successful innovations in the past, I mean, the things that really stand out is so simple, so obvious to customer why this is a better product, whether it's [indiscernible] or ComfortSoft waistband or X-TEMP, maybe drive a little more on Fresh IQ. Isn't that kind of innovation where it's going to be really obvious with the consumer why it is a better product and is that innovation flow-through in terms of [indiscernible] or is that just in a different shooter product that similar price point?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it does flow through our consumer research as it's very simple for the consumer to understand. It's a concern that many consumers have. And this is our provision of our elimination of that concern. It is -- in certain cases, it's a modest pr
componenttext: Well, I think it does flow through our consumer research as it's very simple for the consumer to understand. It's a concern that many consumers have. And this is our provision of our elimination of that concern. It is -- in certain cases, it's a modest premium. In others, it's no premium to the current core business. And our purchase intent measures indicate that the consumer clearly understands and desires it.

componenttext: Congrats, Rich and Gerald. I guess, this question's for Rick, I think. Just back to the inventory and the margins. I guess, should we expect any more inventory management costs that might linger into the back half of this fiscal year? Just trying to understand if or when we should expect gross margins to potentially flatten out or even expand again. And to that point, just what should inventory dollar growth, inclusive of the new acquisition deals, look like as we move through Q3 and Q4?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me talk about the first part of your question. We don't expect any more costs to flow through. The $20 million that we referred to at the beginning of the year, being in the first half, did flow through. We're done with our projects, our invento
componenttext: Well, let me talk about the first part of your question. We don't expect any more costs to flow through. The $20 million that we referred to at the beginning of the year, being in the first half, did flow through. We're done with our projects, our inventory management projects. As a result, you should see -- at the end of Q3, you should see ex acquisitions, Pacific Brands and Champion, you should see inventory actually go down in real terms. And so -- and then continue down in the fourth quarter as well. So we kind of crossed the bridge, if you will, in terms of inventory in terms of absolute dollars. So what if had on the back half in terms of margins? If you look at the impact in Q2 of the $12 million that I referred to, it was maybe a basis point hit to the margins, and margins were donated little less than that. So we would naturally be up in margins in Q2. Similar in Q1 as well. So the we're looking -- we've always said that we look for gross margins in the first half to be down as a result of the inventory costs, but to be up in the back half of the year as those away and the traditional drivers of margin expansion kick in, manufacturing efficiencies, synergies, et cetera, et cetera.

Activewear's strongest quarters is the third quarter, and that tends to mix our margin down a little bit. The margins in Activewear tend to be in the lower. So be careful as you're looking at the those 2 quarters. Those are what you're going to need to keep in mind in terms of operating margins -- well, before -- operating margins for the back half is -- again, the operating margins that we're getting from our new acquisitions, Pac Brands and Champion Europe, will be about -- have about 100 basis point impact on our margins for the back half at an operating profit margin basis. So 50 basis points for the full year, about 100 basis -- you do the math on the guidance, that's what it'll tell you. So we -- there will be a couple of things that will -- the base business should show a nice improvement in both gross margin and operating margin in the back half of the year.

componenttext: And on the Hanes Activewear question, let me just answer that. From the standpoint of Hanes Activewear, it's a fairly small piece of our total Activewear business. It's a basic T-shirt business sold in the mass channel. We see fluctuations in space as retailers have it from time to time. We had expected this adjustment, and it just happened to come in the second half and as we have planned and is an offset year-on-year. It's behind us. As we look to the balance of the year, that business will begin its footing as well and should show nice performance for the balance of the year.

componenttext: From the standpoint of the Champion U.S. business, as we discussed in the half or in the quarter of the business was flat as we head headwinds of the pipes from last year and some bankruptcies in the sports specialty business that were offset by a return to growth in the mass business as well as strong performance out of our college bookstore business. As we look to the back half of the year, we expect to see sequentially improving business within Champion U.S. as it returns to growth, again, as we overcome some of the headwinds out of the sports specialty bankruptcies with drink out of our mass and college bookstore businesses.

componenttext: No. What I spoke about was in Innerwear. There was the pipes that we had last year were very high as we expended a lot of space within our X-TEMP basics business. We anticipate that makes so much of our business that we have seen POS eventually the shipments balance out within that. And as we look now to the back half of our year, we have our various initiatives coming on line with our basics business as well as the launch of our Fresh IQ that you'll see the shipments ramp as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would remind you is that in the fourth quarter, we assumed that -- at the low end of our guidance that we'd continue to have the impact of the extremely warm weather we had last year, so there was no improvement upon that. We also had a numbe
componenttext: Well, what I would remind you is that in the fourth quarter, we assumed that -- at the low end of our guidance that we'd continue to have the impact of the extremely warm weather we had last year, so there was no improvement upon that. We also had a number of initiatives in place behind our core basics business, our focus on the core initiatives that are going to ramp during the second half of the year, including our Fresh IQ and. And certainly, we closed on our Champion and Pacific Brands acquisitions that also give us further year-on-year improvements. So we've got a number of initiatives working our way. And if the weather were to improve, then we'll moving further towards the higher end of our guidance. So I think we're well positioned in that case. I would remind you, as compared to many of the businesses that speak to you about bookings, our businesses overall are 85% replenishment. So hours is very much based on POSs derived from purchases and while there are very much dependent on pre-bookings and perhaps the conservatism of buyers and their concerns about the prior year, we were -- we have assumed that lower end of the guidance from standpoint of the weather, but we are positioned such that if the higher end comes, we've got the inventory in place and our replenishment model allows us to pursue the growth going forward.
