componenttext: This is Pallavi on the line for Christian. Can you speak a little bit about kind of the rollout of this new Fresh IQ product? What we can see in terms of merchandising? And any expectations for kind of being able to gain shelf space with your retail partners?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Fresh IQ is an odor control technology that mechanically attacks bacteria. What -- it is a technology we're rolling out right now. It began to rollout in this quarter -- in the third quarter and we'll continue to do so through the balance of the yea
componenttext: Sure. Fresh IQ is an odor control technology that mechanically attacks bacteria. What -- it is a technology we're rolling out right now. It began to rollout in this quarter -- in the third quarter and we'll continue to do so through the balance of the year. Is really one of our -- we've gotten some of the strongest response from consumers we've seen in some time from a purchase intent standpoint. And it'll roll out across our men's basics, underwear and socks as well as a number of our Champion items. It's going to be available across all of our men's underwear and socks. So it's really rolling across both our core as well as our innovation platforms such as X-TEMP or ComfortBlend. It's very similar to what we did a decade ago or so with our TAGLESS tee. The retailers are very excited about this, and you'll see both some shelf expansion, but you'll also see significant promotion activity behind it as we roll late into the third quarter and into the holiday period, and we'll also begin our media support in the fall as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Susan Anderson from FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Susan Anderson from FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First I want to say congrats Rich on your retirement. You've done an amazing job over the past 10 years. And you'll definitely be missed. I hopped on a bit late. I don't know if you can go over, maybe, just kind of your thoughts around the back half in te
componenttext: First I want to say congrats Rich on your retirement. You've done an amazing job over the past 10 years. And you'll definitely be missed. I hopped on a bit late. I don't know if you can go over, maybe, just kind of your thoughts around the back half in terms of the Innerwear and Activewear categories on how you see the core businesses, excluding the acquisitions growing in the back half.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me start with the Innerwear category. Well, what I would say is, right now, it's in the first half of their, it's really performed as we expected. It was up nicely in Q1, up over 1 percentage point in Q1. And we had expected it to be down in ship
componenttext: Yes. Let me start with the Innerwear category. Well, what I would say is, right now, it's in the first half of their, it's really performed as we expected. It was up nicely in Q1, up over 1 percentage point in Q1. And we had expected it to be down in shipments in Q2 as we overlapped the pretty substantial space gains that we experienced in our basics business and X-TEMP last year. As we look to the balance of the year and we execute our initiatives behind our focus on the core initiative as well as we're seeing sequentially improving trends in our bra business, we feel good that we'll have very positive momentum, along with now our new innovation in Fresh IQ in the Innerwear business as we look to the second half. As I turn to the Activewear business, we were down in Q2, but again, as expected after coming off of a strong first quarter, where we were up 2.8% in first quarter. In the Q2, Hanes Activewear was the key driver of our decline for the quarter as we had some space adjustments in some of our key customers. In Champion, we did bear the brunt of overlapping big pipes in Q2 of last year as well as we did have some headwinds from bankruptcies in the sports specialty. But they were -- Champion overall was flat because we saw mid-single-digit results in our mass business and double-digit growth within our college bookstore business. And our Champion POS and sports specialty, in spite of the challenges with bankruptcies, was actually up quite a bit in the quarter, up double-digit basis. So overall, we expect Activewear to return to growth as we put the Hanes Activewear adjustments of Q2 behind us. And we continue to see momentum in the business going forward. What I do -- would say, too, is on a global basis, the Champion brand had a solid quarter and grew nicely in the quarter, with particular strength in Japan. As we look at Champion on a global basis in the second half, we expect that growth to continue to accelerate. And then the addition of Champion Europe will just further accelerate growth on top of that.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then on the Women's side, it sounds like the panties did well. Maybe if you could touch on a little bit, the bra business and how you expect that to play out in the back half. Definitely, it seems like the presentation looks ver
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then on the Women's side, it sounds like the panties did well. Maybe if you could touch on a little bit, the bra business and how you expect that to play out in the back half. Definitely, it seems like the presentation looks very cleaned up and with your newer brand assortment  much cleaner in the stores. And then, maybe, if you could touch on too how the traditional bras are performing versus more active or comfort-type bras.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'd be happy to. The bra business actually did show positive growth within the quarter, as we overlapped our brand consolidation business. This was up mid-single digits within the quarter. So we see positive trend in that business. As we look to the
componenttext: Sure. I'd be happy to. The bra business actually did show positive growth within the quarter, as we overlapped our brand consolidation business. This was up mid-single digits within the quarter. So we see positive trend in that business. As we look to the balance of the year and we continue to see the power of our brand consolidation, we do believe there'll be positive trend in the second half of that business as well. We see growth in 2 places, certainly, in our -- some of our key brands such as Bali, we see solid growth. But also, as you alluded to, very much we're seeing growth in that ComfortFlex Fit model, which is the blending of the active and the casual, the athleisure, if you will, of the bras coming together. And the Hanes business, in particular, is doing very well in that segment.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jay Sole from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jay Sole from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question's on cotton. The price of cotton has jumped a little bit in the last couple of months. Can you talk about why you think that is? And what your outlook for cotton is? And how might that impact cost of goods sold going forward?
componenttext: My question's on cotton. The price of cotton has jumped a little bit in the last couple of months. Can you talk about why you think that is? And what your outlook for cotton is? And how might that impact cost of goods sold going forward?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, cotton always -- is a little bit volatile, and it'll trade within the range. We don't necessarily believe that the pricing that you see on cotton today is something that's going to be around forever. But we -- this is the beauty of our dollar cost a
componenttext: Well, cotton always -- is a little bit volatile, and it'll trade within the range. We don't necessarily believe that the pricing that you see on cotton today is something that's going to be around forever. But we -- this is the beauty of our dollar cost averaging approach to hedging cotton. We're hedged out through essentially through the middle of next year, P&L basis, at the prices that were -- at mid-60-ish type range. So we're feeling pretty good about that. And we'll see where it goes. It's -- again, it's hard to predict.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, the second question is on the increase in the pretax acquisition integration charges of $20 million. Can you just explain how the Champion Europe and Pacific Brand deals closing sooner drive higher purchase accounting adjustments?
componenttext: Okay. And then, the second question is on the increase in the pretax acquisition integration charges of $20 million. Can you just explain how the Champion Europe and Pacific Brand deals closing sooner drive higher purchase accounting adjustments?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it really wasn't the timing of it. It would -- what generally happens is we -- once we actually acquire the company, we're able to get inside their books a little bit more and we're then able to -- are able to do the very complex purchase accounting
componenttext: Well, it really wasn't the timing of it. It would -- what generally happens is we -- once we actually acquire the company, we're able to get inside their books a little bit more and we're then able to -- are able to do the very complex purchase accounting processes that we have to go through under GAAP. And those are sometimes, from the outside, a little hard to adjust -- or to assess. After we got in, we found that they were about roughly $20 million higher than we originally thought. I would point out, though, Jay, it's all noncash, it's all just accounting stuff. So not cash at all. So while it was up $20 million, it was all noncash items.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich and Gerald, congratulations to you both. I have a couple of quick questions. The first one, I wanted to see, Rich or Gerald, kind of on some of the channel shifts going on in the category, in apparel generally, but I don't think Innerwear that's on t
componenttext: Rich and Gerald, congratulations to you both. I have a couple of quick questions. The first one, I wanted to see, Rich or Gerald, kind of on some of the channel shifts going on in the category, in apparel generally, but I don't think Innerwear that's on the basic category you compete in are immune to it -- a lot of traffic's moving online -- and the basket sizes given your price points maybe doesn't fit quite as well, given shipping costs and things like that. Can you kind of dive in on where you stand with Amazon and hanes.com and walmart.com and target.com and some of the key kind of e-commerce channels and how you're thinking about positioning of your business out a few years and your brand out a few years if this kind of consumer behavior shift continues or even accelerates in the basics and Innerwear category. I'd love your thoughts on that?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We certainly have seen a shift in the consumer's mind to learn and engage with brands from a learning standpoint as well as buying increasingly online. And our categories have seen some of those same shifts, whether they were basics or certainly the
componenttext: Yes. We certainly have seen a shift in the consumer's mind to learn and engage with brands from a learning standpoint as well as buying increasingly online. And our categories have seen some of those same shifts, whether they were basics or certainly the active wear business or the intimates business for that matter. And we've been pretty clear for a while that we're going to invest the resources, both people and dollars, to make sure that we get full advantage of that. Within the U.S., for example. We saw, again, a mid-teens growth in our online business during the quarter. And in Europe, we also see a number of those markets are highly developed from an online standpoint. We're organizing equally strongly to go after that business and drive those businesses as well. And as we've stated before, our shares online or we have leading shares. They're not as fully developed as they are in the bricks-and-mortar and we'll continue to work to drive those and we're going to do that really by working across all the elements of that online channel, which would include working with our bricks-and-mortar very closely and helping drive their businesses. And they understand that our learning in our brands are an important avenue to lead people to their site. Certainly, we could continue to develop our own sites, not only as a selling location, but as a communication location of our brand positionings and what our brands have to offer. And then, certainly, from the standpoint of working with the major pure plays, we've got a significant amount of effort against that, and we're seeing very strong results as we look at that. Overall, in the U.S., our business is now 8% online and is continuing to grow. And we've got a lot of focus on that going forward.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the shipping issue, shipping cost issue at basket sizes? I'm just wondering how you're thinking about or if you're seeing that having an effect on the e-commerce business.
componenttext: And on the shipping issue, shipping cost issue at basket sizes? I'm just wondering how you're thinking about or if you're seeing that having an effect on the e-commerce business.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't really see -- we see similar economics from the standpoint of, for us, of shipping our online customers relative to our wholesale customers. From the standpoint of the online, the emergence of free freight at certain levels and things like that.
componenttext: We don't really see -- we see similar economics from the standpoint of, for us, of shipping our online customers relative to our wholesale customers. From the standpoint of the online, the emergence of free freight at certain levels and things like that. It's certainly generated even more and more sales of even basics online as the bar for consumers to get to some level of free postage has gotten lower and lower. Some of our best developed -- I will just add -- some of our best developed categories were the early ones where -- such as intimates, that reached that bar earlier.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Got you. And then one quick follow-up guys, on Fresh IQ. If I look back to some of your big successful innovations in the past, I mean, the things that really stand out it's so simple and it's -- and it's so obvious to the customer why this is a
componenttext: Got you. Got you. And then one quick follow-up guys, on Fresh IQ. If I look back to some of your big successful innovations in the past, I mean, the things that really stand out it's so simple and it's -- and it's so obvious to the customer why this is a better product, whether it's TAGLESS tee or ComfortSoft waistband or X-TEMPs. Maybe dive in a little bit more on Fresh IQ. Is it that kind of innovation where it's going to be really obvious to the consumer why this is a better product? And does that innovation flow-through in terms of higher price points? Or is it just a differentiated product at a similar price point?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it does flow through our consumer research says it's very simple for the consumer to understand. It's a concern that many consumers have. And this is a prevention provision our elimination of that concern. It is -- in certain cases, it's a m
componenttext: Well, I think it does flow through our consumer research says it's very simple for the consumer to understand. It's a concern that many consumers have. And this is a prevention provision our elimination of that concern. It is -- in certain cases, it's a modest premium. In others, it's no premium to the current core business. And our purchase intent says -- measures indicate that the consumer clearly understands and desires it.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ike Boruchow with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ike Boruchow with Wells Fargo.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats Rich and Gerald. I guess, this question's for Rick, I think. Just back to the inventory and the margins. Just, I guess, should we expect any more inventory management costs that might linger into the back half of this fiscal year? Just trying to
componenttext: Congrats Rich and Gerald. I guess, this question's for Rick, I think. Just back to the inventory and the margins. Just, I guess, should we expect any more inventory management costs that might linger into the back half of this fiscal year? Just trying to understand if or when we should expect gross margins to potentially flatten out or even expand again. And to that point, just what should inventory dollar growth, inclusive of the new acquisition deals, look like as we move through Q3 and Q4?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me talk about the first part of your question. We don't expect any more costs to flow through. The $20 million that we referred to at the beginning of the year, it was being in the first half, did flow through. We're done with our projects, whic
componenttext: Well, let me talk about the first part of your question. We don't expect any more costs to flow through. The $20 million that we referred to at the beginning of the year, it was being in the first half, did flow through. We're done with our projects, which is our inventory management projects. As a result, you should see -- at the end of Q3, you should see ex acquisitions, Pacific Brands and Champion, you should see inventory actually go down in real terms. And so -- and then continue down in the fourth quarter as well. So we kind of crossed the bridge, if you will, in terms of inventory, in terms of absolute dollars. So what effect does that have on the back half in terms of margins? If you look at the impact in Q2 of the $12 million that I referred to, that was an 80 basis point hit to the margins, and margins were down a little less than that. So we would actually have been up in margins in Q2. Same would have been true in Q1 as well. So the -- so we're looking -- we've always said that we looked for gross margins in the first half to be down as a result of the inventory costs, but to be up in the back half of the year as those go away and the traditional drivers of margin expansion kick in, manufacturing efficiencies, synergies, et cetera, et cetera.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Anna Andreeva from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Anna Andreeva from Oppenheimer.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a follow-up on the gross margin question. Just any variability in how we should model the back half 3Q versus 4Q. I think you have the easier compare in the third quarter. And then secondly, just to follow up on the Hanes Activewear. I think, you
componenttext: I guess, a follow-up on the gross margin question. Just any variability in how we should model the back half 3Q versus 4Q. I think you have the easier compare in the third quarter. And then secondly, just to follow up on the Hanes Activewear. I think, you said was a drag in the second quarter. You mentioned some cadence adjustments at some of your customers. Maybe additional color on that. And remind us about the size of Hanes Activewear business.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, let me talk about the gross margins in the back half. There are a couple of things that you should remember -- that we've always told you. Activewear's strongest quarter is the third quarter, and that tends to mix our margins down a little bi
componenttext: Well, first, let me talk about the gross margins in the back half. There are a couple of things that you should remember -- that we've always told you. Activewear's strongest quarter is the third quarter, and that tends to mix our margins down a little bit. The margins in Activewear tend to be a little lower. So be careful as you're looking at the -- at those 2 quarters. The other thing that you're going to keep in mind in terms of operating margins -- well, before -- yes, operating margins for the back half is, again, the operating margins that we're getting from our new acquisitions: Pac Brands and Champion Europe, will be about -- will have about 100 basis point impact on our margins for the back half at an operating profit margin basis. So 50 basis points for the full year, about 100 -- if you do the math on the guidance, that's what it'll tell you. So we -- there will be a couple of things that will -- but then at [ph] the base business should show nice improvement in both gross margin and operating margin in the back half of the year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the Hanes Activewear question, let me just answer that. From the standpoint of Hanes Activewear, it's a fairly small piece of our total Activewear business. It's a basic fleece and T-shirt business sold in the mass channel. We see fluctuations in s
componenttext: And on the Hanes Activewear question, let me just answer that. From the standpoint of Hanes Activewear, it's a fairly small piece of our total Activewear business. It's a basic fleece and T-shirt business sold in the mass channel. We see fluctuations in space as retailers have it from time to time. We had expected this adjustment, and it just happened to come in the second half and as we had planned and is an offset year-on-year. It's behind us. As we look to the balance of the year, that business will regain its footing as well and should show nice performance for the balance of the year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Simeon Siegel from Nomura Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Simeon Siegel from Nomura Securities.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich and Gerald congrats to both of you on the changes. Just a quick follow-up on Ike's question. I think -- Rick, I think you gave it a 51 million of Champion Europe for inventory. Do you know what you expect the Pacific Brands to add to the inventory ba
componenttext: Rich and Gerald congrats to both of you on the changes. Just a quick follow-up on Ike's question. I think -- Rick, I think you gave it a 51 million of Champion Europe for inventory. Do you know what you expect the Pacific Brands to add to the inventory balance for this year, 3Q and year-end? And then, just what are your thoughts on Champion U.S. going forward? Sorry if I missed it, but did you guys say what you expect the total change in Activewear this year to be just in light of the challenges and the puts and takes?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as Pac Brands' impact on inventories for the balance of the year, we're still assessing that as we just acquired them, and we're still going through the purchase accounting process for them. So once we get past that, we'll give you a better feel fo
componenttext: As far as Pac Brands' impact on inventories for the balance of the year, we're still assessing that as we just acquired them, and we're still going through the purchase accounting process for them. So once we get past that, we'll give you a better feel for it.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From the standpoint of the Champion U.S. business, as we discussed in the half or in the quarter, the business was flat as we had -- the headwinds of the pipes from last year and some bankruptcies in the sports specialty business that were offset by a ret
componenttext: From the standpoint of the Champion U.S. business, as we discussed in the half or in the quarter, the business was flat as we had -- the headwinds of the pipes from last year and some bankruptcies in the sports specialty business that were offset by a return to growth in the mass business as well as strong performance out of our college bookstore business. As we look to the back half of the year, we expect to see sequentially improving business within Champion U.S. as it returns to growth, again, as we overcome some of the headwinds out of the sports specialty bankruptcies, which drain out of our mass and college bookstore businesses.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jim Duffy from Stifel.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jim Duffy from Stifel.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions for me. Can you talk some more about the timing of shipment shifts that you referenced? Was that a pull-forward into 1Q or a push into 3Q? And what categories was that for?
componenttext: A couple of questions for me. Can you talk some more about the timing of shipment shifts that you referenced? Was that a pull-forward into 1Q or a push into 3Q? And what categories was that for?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. What I spoke about was in Innerwear. There was the pipes that we had last year were very high as we expanded a lot of space within our X-TEMP basics business. As we overlapped this year, we didn't have that same lift of pipes. Our POS continued to be
componenttext: No. What I spoke about was in Innerwear. There was the pipes that we had last year were very high as we expanded a lot of space within our X-TEMP basics business. As we overlapped this year, we didn't have that same lift of pipes. Our POS continued to be strong in the quarter in our basics business, and in fact, for the first 6 months of the year has been favorable all year in the basics business. So we're seeing strong growth there. We anticipate that like so much of our business that if you see POS strength, eventually the shipments balance out with that. And as we look now to the back half of our year, we have our various initiatives coming on line with our basics business as well as the launch of our Fresh IQ that you'll see the shipments ramp as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2Q a year ago, I recall you had, I believe, it was inventory destocking issues with a large retailer. But yet, you're referencing that as a difficult compare? Do I have that wrong?
componenttext: 2Q a year ago, I recall you had, I believe, it was inventory destocking issues with a large retailer. But yet, you're referencing that as a difficult compare? Do I have that wrong?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. In fact, you have that wrong. That was in Q3 of last year.
componenttext: No. In fact, you have that wrong. That was in Q3 of last year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Rick, question for you. With respect to businesses acquired during 2016, what do you expect inventory balances to be at year-end?
componenttext: Okay. And then, Rick, question for you. With respect to businesses acquired during 2016, what do you expect inventory balances to be at year-end?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jim, as I just said, I mean, I've heard it on the previous question, we're still going through the purchase accounting process with Pac Brands. And so that can have an impact on what the actual inventory number ends up being. So I'd rather hold off
componenttext: Well, Jim, as I just said, I mean, I've heard it on the previous question, we're still going through the purchase accounting process with Pac Brands. And so that can have an impact on what the actual inventory number ends up being. So I'd rather hold off on giving you that just now.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question for today comes from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: And our final question for today comes from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, I'm sorry Rich and Gerald congrats again on the changes. On -- let me ask you on inventory. Seeing as it's it'll be 9 months after you guys first mentioned the inventory actions before in our seats we see the inventory dollars start to come down due
componenttext: Rick, I'm sorry Rich and Gerald congrats again on the changes. On -- let me ask you on inventory. Seeing as it's it'll be 9 months after you guys first mentioned the inventory actions before in our seats we see the inventory dollars start to come down due to the lead times in the business. So you took some action earlier in the year, closed down some factories and that gets the back half inventory a lot dollars lower. But now that we're past that, as you start looking ahead to the next 9 months and into 2017, given everything that is going on with retail right now, do you bring the factories back up to capacity? Or can you tell us how you're thinking about the longer-term outlook from a production standpoint today?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. This is Gerald. What I would say is as we look at it, yes, you began to see the inventories come down as a function of the time we took out earlier. We are also now reaching our peak period from those shipments for back-to-school and into ho
componenttext: Yes, Michael. This is Gerald. What I would say is as we look at it, yes, you began to see the inventories come down as a function of the time we took out earlier. We are also now reaching our peak period from those shipments for back-to-school and into holiday that further draws down that inventory so our factories are up now, and they're manufacturing at a normalized rate to now as inventories come down to balance out the production going forward. And you'll continue to see inventories fall through the balance of the year.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Even at capacity in the factories, you'll still see the inventories come down?
componenttext: Even at capacity in the factories, you'll still see the inventories come down?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. Yes.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's interesting. And then, just because there's so much volatility in the compare, as we look ahead to the -- thanks for the detail on the fourth quarter, guys -- as we look ahead to the fourth quarter, can you help us think about the ramp there?
componenttext: Okay. That's interesting. And then, just because there's so much volatility in the compare, as we look ahead to the -- thanks for the detail on the fourth quarter, guys -- as we look ahead to the fourth quarter, can you help us think about the ramp there? There's just been a lot of wholesalers in the last 2 weeks have -- went into very cautious comments out of some of the discrete wholesale channels. You guys have some pretty volatile compares in the fourth quarter, and then you did have some -- we didn't think you'd have as much weather volatility last year, but you guys pointed out we do have some categories that have a lot of sweatshirts and fleece and those kinds of things. Can you tell us how -- maybe some of the building blocks to get to what you've baked into the fourth quarter this year against those compares?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would remind you is that in the fourth quarter, we assumed that -- at the low end of our guidance that we'd continue to have the impact of the extremely warm weather we had last year, so there was no improvement upon that. We also had a numbe
componenttext: Well, what I would remind you is that in the fourth quarter, we assumed that -- at the low end of our guidance that we'd continue to have the impact of the extremely warm weather we had last year, so there was no improvement upon that. We also had a number of initiatives in place behind our core basics business, our focus on the core initiatives that are going to ramp during the second half of the year, including our Fresh IQ. And then, certainly, we've closed on our Champion and Pacific Brands acquisitions that also give us further year-on-year improvements. So we've got a number of initiatives working our way. And if the weather were to improve, then we move even further towards the higher end of our guidance. So I think we're well positioned in that case. I would remind you, as compared to many of the businesses that speak to you about bookings, our businesses overall are 85% replenishment. So ours is very much based on POSs derived from purchases, and while they are very much dependent on pre-bookings and perhaps the conservatism of buyers and their concerns about the prior year, we were -- we have assumed that lower end of the guidance from standpoint of the weather, but we are positioned such that if the higher end comes, we've got the inventory in place and our replenishment model allows us to pursue that growth going forward.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hanesbrands Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the floor over to T.C. Robillard, Chief Investor
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hanesbrands Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the floor over to T.C. Robillard, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Hanesbrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the third quarter of 2016.Hopefully, everyone has had a chance review the news r
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Hanesbrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the third quarter of 2016.
Hopefully, everyone has had a chance review the news release we issued earlier today. The news release, updated FAQ document and a replay of this call can be found in the Investors section of our hanes.com website.
On the call today, we may make forward-looking statements either in our prepared remarks or in the associated question-and-answer session. These statements are based on current expectations or beliefs and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. These risks are detailed in our various filings with the SEC and may be found on our website as well as in our news releases. The company does not undertake to update or revise any forward-looking statements, which speak only to the time at which they are made. Unless otherwise noted, today's references to our consolidated financial results as well as our 2016 guidance represent continuing operations and exclude all onetime charges and expenses. Additional information, including a reconciliation of these and other non-GAAP performance measures to GAAP, can be found in today's press release. 
With me on the call today are Gerald Evans, our Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Moss, our Chief Financial Officer. For today's call, Gerald and Rick will provide some brief remarks, and then we'll open it up to your questions. 
I will now turn the call over to Gerald.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, T.C. We're having a great year. Our sales initiatives have reaccelerated organic growth in several of our core business lines. Our acquisitions both past and present are performing extremely well. Our inventory level is declining. And cash flow
componenttext:
Thank you, T.C. We're having a great year. Our sales initiatives have reaccelerated organic growth in several of our core business lines. Our acquisitions both past and present are performing extremely well. Our inventory level is declining. And cash flow from operations is already $300 million ahead of last year. Overall our business is tracking to our plans and remain constant ability to deliver our full year guidance. 
Our business model is as strong as ever and continues to create significant value for our shareholders. The real power of our model comes from its diversification. We have a variety of different levers that allow us to consistently grow both revenue and earnings per share, while at the same time, generate significant amounts of cash flow. It's not just one strategy or one facet of our business, it's a number of them, working together that drive strong consistent results. And this was evident once again in our third quarter as 3 different levers combined to drive and 11% increase in revenue, a 12% increase in earnings per share and a record level of cash flow from operations. 
The first lever contributing to our strong results was our focus on the core initiatives. If you recall, at the beginning of the year, we highlighted various sales initiatives to drive second half growth in parts of our core. And these initiatives delivered as we saw accelerated organic growth across several of our business lines. 
For the quarter, our Basics revenue increased 9% organically driven by a 20% growth in men's underwear as we gain market share and began to flow in shipments of our new odor control innovation, Fresh IQ. Year-to-date, our Basics business is up 2% organically and we expect momentum to continue through the fourth quarter as our holiday promotions are in place and we begun to advertise behind Fresh IQ. 
Global Champion for the quarter delivered low single-digit organic revenue growth driven by low double-digit growth in the mass channel and strong double-digit organic growth in Japan. And in terms of our U.S. online business, sales across all channels increased 17% in the quarter. 
The second lever of our business model that drove strong third quarter results was our acquisition strategy. We continue to generate significant synergies from our prior acquisitions, including Hanes Europe, Knights Apparel and Maidenform, which continues to create synergies even 3 years after closing. For the full year, we remain on track to achieve our target of $40 million in acquisition synergies. 
We also benefited from the addition of Champion Europe and Pacific Brands. Both businesses drove revenue and operating profit results that exceeded our plan, further reinforcing our excitement about these acquisitions. These are great business with great brand and very strong management team that are already creating value for our shareholders. We remain on schedule with the integration planning and we're confident in our ability to deliver over $125 million in combined annual operating profit within 3 years. 
And the third level of our business model that drove strong results in the quarter was our cash generation strategy. When we exited the fourth quarter last year, the weather-driven slowdown created an inventory overhand that temporarily impacted our cash flow. While there have been some skeptics, we communicated a specific strategy to reduce inventory and generate record levels of cash flow, and that's exactly what we've done. Inventory in the quarter, excluding recent acquisitions declined significantly from the second quarter's level, which in turn help drive $337 million in cash flow from operations. And as we expected, our acquisition and integration expenses continue to decline, all of which keeps us firmly on track to deliver our cash flow guidance for the year. 
So in summary, we had a great quarter. And this combined, with our full year outlook, represents further proof that our business model is as strong as ever and continues to create significant long-term returns for our shareholders. Looking forward, we believe we are extremely well positioned to deliver on average mid-single digit revenue growth and double-digit EPS growth for many years to come. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerald. We delivered strong operating results for the quarter. Our sales initiatives reaccelerated organic growth across multiple business lines. Our inventory reduction actions generated record levels of cash flow from operations. Our acquisition
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerald. We delivered strong operating results for the quarter. Our sales initiatives reaccelerated organic growth across multiple business lines. Our inventory reduction actions generated record levels of cash flow from operations. Our acquisitions both past and present posted better-than-expected profit results. And our acquisition- and integration-related expenses continue to decline. 
Now let me walk you through the specifics for the quarter. Sales increased 11% over last year and like many diversified global companies, we had various puts and takes across our multiple business lines. Acquisitions contributed nicely as Champion Europe, Pacific Brands and the acquired Champion license in Japan added approximately $180 million of revenue in the quarter. We delivered strong organic growth in several business lines, including Basics, Champion of mass, Gear for Sports, Champion Japan and online. This growth was offset by a decline in Champion in the sports speciality channel as well as a decline in our U.S. direct-to-consumer business where we're proactively transitioning to a growth model by exiting our legacy catalog business and removing noncore offerings. 
Looking at our 2 largest segments, Innerwear sales increased 2% organically in the quarter. Our Basics business was up 9% over last year, including a 20% increase in men's underwear. This strong organic growth was driven by our various focus on the core sales initiatives, including increased marketing and promotion as well as the launch of Fresh IQ, the first innovation in our core in over a decade. 
Year-to-date, our Basics business is up 2% with the growth evenly balanced across all product categories. This is partially offset by the expected decline in intimates as we annivery-ied the large pipe of Hanes bras in last year's third quarter. 
Turning to our Activewear segment. Sales declined 2% in the quarter. Our Champion business at mass increased by over 10% organically as our refresh product offering continues to resonate with consumers. 
Gear for Sports, which is our college bookstore business, also delivered organic growth in the quarter, up mid-single digits over last year. This growth is more than offset by declines in Champion in the sports specialty channel due to the bankruptcies of certain sporting goods retailers in the U.S. While we're disappointed with results in this channel, we believe the headwind is temporary. More importantly, we expect this channel to return to growth in 2017 as our POS trends remain positive at key accounts. We secured new space and we lap the impact from the bankruptcies. 
Switching to margins. Now that our inventory-related actions are behind us, as expected, our gross margins returned to growth in the quarter increasing 60 basis points over last year, while operating margins decreased 40 basis points due to the short-term dilution from recent acquisitions. Adjusting for these acquisitions, operating margins increased 30 basis points over last year driven by synergies from Hanes Europe, Knights Apparel and Maidenform. 
Interest and other expense increased roughly $13 million over last year as a result of the higher debt balances associated with the acquisitions of Champion Europe [indiscernible] brands. 
The tax rate in the quarter was roughly 6%, bringing our year-to-date tax rate to 7%, which is in line with our full year expectation of a high single digit rate. 
Earnings per share of $0.56 increased 12% over last year and came in at the midpoint of our guidance range. 
Turning to inventory cash flow. Inventory in the quarter, excluding approximately $173 million from recent acquisitions, declined by roughly $124 million from second quarter's level as our actions to reduce inventory continued to deliver results. This, in turn, helped generate $337 million in cash flow from operations, a record for any quarter in our history. Year-to-date, cash flow from operations is roughly $300 million higher than last year, which puts us right on track to deliver on our cash flow guidance for the full year. 
Touching briefly on guidance. While still within our initial range, we've narrowed our full year outlook. This reflects the expected retailer caution heading into the holiday season. If holiday is, in fact, more robust, then that would represent upside to our guidance. At the midpoint, our guidance now implies approximately 8% growth in revenue, roughly 10% growth in operating profit, approximately 15% growth in EPS and $775 million in cash flow from operations. 
In terms of acquisition and integration-related charges, our guidance of approximately $180 million remains unchanged and represents a decline of nearly $90 million from last year. Looking to next year, despite the addition of nearly $1 billion in acquisitions this year, we expect these charges to take another significant step down in 2017 as we benefit from integration efficiencies and leverage our prior foundational investments. 
So in closing, let me in right where Gerald began. We're having a great year, our sales initiatives have reaccelerated organic growth in several of our core business lines. Our acquisitions both past and present are performing extremely well. Our inventory levels declining and cash flow from operations is already $300 million ahead of last year. Overall, our business is tracking to our plan, and we remain confident in our ability to deliver on our full year guidance. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to T.C.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk alluded about the trends that you're seeing in the core mass channel in the U.S. How do you feel about inventories in the channel? And how is your growth thinking, been changing over the course of the year? What are your expectations that you look toward the end of the year in 2017?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gerald. Let me take that question. First of all, I want to say that the year is really unfolding as we expected. We had a great Q3. We put a number of sales initiatives in early in the year, and they've begun to take hold that really helped drive
componenttext: This is Gerald. Let me take that question. First of all, I want to say that the year is really unfolding as we expected. We had a great Q3. We put a number of sales initiatives in early in the year, and they've begun to take hold that really helped drive that strong results in the quarter, up 11% in total revenue growth and up 12% in EPS. Those sales initiatives resulted and drive a very strong Basics results for us in the quarter, up 9%, up 2% year-to-date, and we see that momentum only continuing to build in the Basics business as we have a number of events planned for the fourth quarter behind our key launches like our Fresh IQ and for the holiday period. We've also seen a pretty strong improvement in our Activewear business sequentially from quarter-to-quarter. And when you back out the impact of the sporting goods bankruptcies, you see very strong, actually, a 1% increase in Activewear for the quarter and really strong performance out of our Champion and mas business as well as positive improvement in our Hanes Activewear business. And also our online growth very positive growth, up 17%, which is actually an accelerated rate of where we've been year-to-date. When we look at specific channel, certainly, we had a very strong back-to-school period as indicated by our Q3 results and continued our share gains in core areas like underwear and socks. So from a mass channel perspective, we feel that it's performing very well for us. We came out of the back-to-school period weather inventories in line, so we feel that we do momentum we're carrying into Q4 as well as our inventories in line and the Basics initiatives we have, that we got a good performance that we'll carry into Q4 and in mass as well.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think for both Champion Europe and Pacific Brands we've been very pleased with the strengths of the businesses themselves and certainly, the management that came with this businesses. You may recall that of both these acquisitions very effectively balanced cost synergies as well as growth opportunities. And we see that our expectations on -- for both are in line. And that certainly we've seen actually Q3 we saw a little better performance out of both than we had anticipated. And as we look to the fourth quarter, as the business skews more heavily to the fourth quarter, so you'll see even a little more impact out of them in the fourth quarter.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could, a follow up on what's going on with the Innerwear category, obviously, delivered here with Fresh IQ platform. But Gerald may be just speak to kind of the dynamic between selling into mass traditional brick-and-mortar versus kind of the evoluti
componenttext: If I could, a follow up on what's going on with the Innerwear category, obviously, delivered here with Fresh IQ platform. But Gerald may be just speak to kind of the dynamic between selling into mass traditional brick-and-mortar versus kind of the evolution of the third-party online. It looks like you guys are transitioning some of the segmenting next year. So can you may be just talk about that dynamic and how you guys are positioned to kind capitalize on that?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Certainly. The power of our sales initiatives showed across all channels and when you look at the Innerwear business across Basics, with that kind of lift, certainly it touched every channel. We do continue to see a shift of apparel sales, in genera
componenttext: Sure. Certainly. The power of our sales initiatives showed across all channels and when you look at the Innerwear business across Basics, with that kind of lift, certainly it touched every channel. We do continue to see a shift of apparel sales, in general, online and our categories are shifting with them. As we've discussed before, we hold the #1 share position in our core categories online. We saw very solid growth really at about 2x the rate of total apparel group growth where our growth trend within the quarter. It is what caused us to take some of our actions within our DTC business, that's a relatively small business for us. And that business really continues to the U.S., outlet stores as well as our own website and legacy catalog business. So frankly, we're taking the step there as well to exit that catalog business, which is the masking, the double-digit growth within our websites and position that business, along with our other segments to grow as apparel ships online. So that's a strategic position we've made to drive growth as well. So we feel good about the direction of Innerwear and we feel good about the momentum we carry into Q4.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I could touch on cash flow. The build year-to-date here should hopefully put to bed some of the concerns around last year's 4Q depressed level and release working cap inventory. But how do you get sort of comfortable that, that continues, I'm
componenttext: And then if I could touch on cash flow. The build year-to-date here should hopefully put to bed some of the concerns around last year's 4Q depressed level and release working cap inventory. But how do you get sort of comfortable that, that continues, I'm assuming the assumption for next year, for the cash, is at the same level, if not higher but really kind of this working cap adjustment sort of behind us.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, let me take that. If you look at our guidance, it implies that the fourth quarter is going to generate about $550 million to $600 million of cash flow from operations. Remember there, the fourth quarter is normally a disproportionately, large p
componenttext: Yes. Sure, let me take that. If you look at our guidance, it implies that the fourth quarter is going to generate about $550 million to $600 million of cash flow from operations. Remember there, the fourth quarter is normally a disproportionately, large percentage of our annual cash flow because of the way the business runs. But let me break that down for you, kind of give you a sense of where that 250 -- or $350 million to -- or probably $550 million to $600 million is coming from. About $250 million of it is coming from net income and other noncash items like depreciation and amortization. If you take our guidance for those fourth quarter, you get to those kinds of numbers. The balance of it, about $300 million to $350 million, come will primarily from working capital. The bulk of it from inventory -- continued inventory reductions as we continue to drive our inventory reduction plans. As well as the normal AR reduction that we always see in Q4. A bit of majority, pickup from accounts payable, a little here and there as well. very confident though that we're going to get to the numbers that we've been talking about.

componenttextpreview: Well, let me first say, as Gerald said a little earlier, the acquisitions, Pac Brands and Champion Europe, are doing better than we expected and that's really constituting the bulk of the difference in our expectations for acquisitions in the year. In ter
componenttext: Well, let me first say, as Gerald said a little earlier, the acquisitions, Pac Brands and Champion Europe, are doing better than we expected and that's really constituting the bulk of the difference in our expectations for acquisitions in the year. In terms of GPM, we did a couple of, as you'll see in our 10-Q, we did a couple of very small tuck-in acquisitions towards the end of the quarter that's will have a really a minimal condition in terms of revenue, really none in terms of profit. These are really more longer-term strategic types of the things, one helps us to expand our sports apparel business into the high school channel. The other represents the acquisition of some stores in Italy and the geography that we're not currently in that. And so these are complementary to what we've been doing in -- to our current business. And so we see these as fairly short term, not desperate -- but that clearly begun impact as the Champion Europe and Pac Brands businesses.

componenttext: That's really helpful, Rick. Quick question on the power up on the Basics business, Innerwear business, the Basics these first the intimate piece. The Basics number was really quite strong. And I think that's the bigger piece. So I'm just trying to kind of triangulate with what were talking about it intimates and how we get comfortable that it's really just a shift in the compared to last year when you ship in all those products and there's not something all going on in the category.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, from the Basics standpoint, there are number of initiatives that grow that kind of lift, that's a great lift on the business, and we think of the initiatives with that behind Fresh IQ going into the fourth quarter and advertising starting next
componenttext: Certainly, from the Basics standpoint, there are number of initiatives that grow that kind of lift, that's a great lift on the business, and we think of the initiatives with that behind Fresh IQ going into the fourth quarter and advertising starting next week, that, that will be a great momentum builder that will carry forward. In the case of intimates, for Q3, it was down as we anniversary-ied the large pipe of our Hanes bras business. You may recall that this pipe contributed to a 9% growth in intimates in last year's Q3. So fairly big lift last year. We feel good about the brand positioning with Hanes, and so forth and the Hanes business continues to capture share. I think from the standpoint of trying to organize out of the vehicle if you take out that noise, and you look back 2 years, we were actually up a little over 2 points over a 2 year-ago period when we didn't have the noise in the pipe in it.

componenttext: Sure. In terms of -- if you do the math, on the guidance, the center point of our guidance would imply an operating margin improvement of about 150 basis points. Most of that is going to come from gross margin as that continues to increase, as we said it would, in the second half of the year. But it will be a combination of the same sorts of things that we've been seeing driving gross margin improvement for the last several years, it's cost savings in our manufacturing facilities, it's synergies, it's strong management of our overhead costs, Innovate-to-Elevate, all of those things will continue to contribute in Q4.

Can you just give us an idea of where you are on those plans and maybe you where expect to be organically versus last year at the end of fourth quarter?

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we ended Q3 down about 70 million units versus last year. That was -- the dollar amount is -- we were up about $15 million organically year-over-year. The inventory mix was a little richer than maybe we had expected, but it was within our range o
componenttext: Sure. So we ended Q3 down about 70 million units versus last year. That was -- the dollar amount is -- we were up about $15 million organically year-over-year. The inventory mix was a little richer than maybe we had expected, but it was within our range of expectations for the quarter. So no surprises per se. In terms of where we expect to be. I would say, you should expect us to be down year-over-year, by the end of the fourth quarter, $100 million to $150 million on inventory.

One question is asked earlier about the revenue from acquisitions, that will be a little higher than we originally -- we're still talking about organic growth in the quarter of 2% to 4%. So it's still really pretty much in line with what we thought.

componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Gerald. Let me just take that. So we've been flowing Fresh IQ in for really through the third quarter as we now into the fourth quarter, it's all-in position, and we will do a big launch behind it, we'll do a combination of TV and digital adv
componenttext: Yes, this is Gerald. Let me just take that. So we've been flowing Fresh IQ in for really through the third quarter as we now into the fourth quarter, it's all-in position, and we will do a big launch behind it, we'll do a combination of TV and digital advertising FX on the digital, effort started 2 weeks ago, we'll turn the TV on next week. And along with that, we'll do a number of shelf display that will encourage trial and bonus packs, and those kind of things to get the consumer to give it a try. This is a big launch for us. It goes across our core underwear and socks as well. Really haven't done a launch like that since that this tee over 10 years ago. And this really reaches a broad base of consumers as we turn on the TV, we encourage that trial, this is a product that's built on one of the biggest concerns of the consumer. And so as you offer that odor elimination option comically to real reason for trial that we're going to back up with great advertising and promotion packs. We get a trial and return to see the repeat. And of course, we're now launching one of the highest traffic periods of the year, so we would expect it to ramp up in the trial and repeat over the next few quarters.

With acquisitions coming in ahead of plan here in the back half, should we think about contribution from the new businesses next year above that $800 million range you guys originally outlined? And any initial color on how should we think about the synergies for '17? And also, just coming into this year, I think we talked about margin expansion being more SG&A-driven. As we approach '17, do you think we should expect a more balanced approach between the gross margin and SG&A?

componenttext: Well, I don't really want to comment much on 2017. We're still in the process of putting our plans together and we'll obviously be giving guidance on 2017 on our next call. We are very pleased with the trends that we have seen and developed and generating synergies from our acquisitions. Every one of our acquisitions is running added plan in terms of the synergies that we're seeing. So we think our integration efforts are being really successful, and we expect to be able to continue to drive those. I think a lot of the things that have driven our -- drivers of our margin improvement in the past couple of years will continue on. We said that we don't really see those as having finite terms. So we'll continue to generate cost savings for manufacturing facilities, we'll continue to generate synergies. I feel will continue to generate gross profit improvement. So all of those drivers will continue on into the future. So we'll be giving you a little more color on that as we get to the '17 guidance on the next call.

componenttext: Sure, let me start with the DTC question. DTC is really U.S.-based business, it's relatively small for us. It concludes our outlet stores, it includes the legacy catalog business and it includes our own websites that we operate. What we've chosen to do is proactively shift it to a growth strategy by exiting the legacy catalog business, it's been in decline for some period of time, and it's really masking the double-digit growth we're seeing out of our website as it follows the trend of so many online and showing growth. And so we've taken that step to transition out of that catalog business. It creates short term headwind, but it allows us to position ourselves for the long-term growth. You want to take the margin question, Rick?

componenttext: I don't want to get into the exact geography of the cash. I would tell you this, we don't consider any of our cash to be trapped on a long-term basis. headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Hanesbrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the third quarter of 2016.Hopefully, everyone has had a chance to review the new
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Hanesbrands Quarterly Investor Conference Call and Webcast. We're pleased to be here today to provide an update on our progress after the third quarter of 2016.
Hopefully, everyone has had a chance to review the news release we issued earlier today. The news release, updated FAQ document and a replay of this call can be found in the Investors section of our hanes.com website.
On the call today, we may make forward-looking statements either in our prepared remarks or in the associated question-and-answer session. These statements are based on current expectations or beliefs and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. These risks are detailed in our various filings with the SEC and may be found on our website as well as in our news releases. The company does not undertake to update or revise any forward-looking statements, which speak only to the time at which they are made. Unless otherwise noted, today's references to our consolidated financial results as well as our 2016 guidance represent continuing operations and exclude all onetime charges and expenses. Additional information, including a reconciliation of these and other non-GAAP performance measures to GAAP, can be found in today's press release.
With me on the call today are Gerald Evans, our Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Moss, our Chief Financial Officer. For today's call, Gerald and Rick will provide some brief remarks, and then we'll open it up to your questions.
I will now turn the call over to Gerald.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, T.C. We're having a great year. Our sales initiatives have reaccelerated organic growth in several of our core business lines. Our acquisitions both past and present are performing extremely well. Our inventory level is declining. And cash flow
componenttext:
Thank you, T.C. We're having a great year. Our sales initiatives have reaccelerated organic growth in several of our core business lines. Our acquisitions both past and present are performing extremely well. Our inventory level is declining. And cash flow from operations is already $300 million ahead of last year. Overall, our business is tracking to our plan, and we remain confident in our ability to deliver a full year guidance.
Our business model is as strong as ever and continues to create significant value for our shareholders. The real power of our model comes from its diversification. We have a variety of different levers that allow us to consistently grow both revenue and earnings per share, while at the same time, generate significant amounts of cash flow. It's not just one strategy or one facet of our business, it's a number of them, working together that drive strong consistent results. And this was evident once again in our third quarter, as 3 different levers combined to drive 11% increase in revenue, 12% increase in earnings per share and a record level of cash flow from operations.
The first lever contributing to our strong results was our focus on the core initiatives. If you recall, at the beginning of the year, we highlighted various sales initiatives to drive second half growth in parts of our core. And these initiatives delivered as we saw accelerated organic growth across several of our business lines.
For the quarter, our Basics revenue increased 9% organically, driven by 20% growth in men's underwear, as we gain market share and began to flow in shipments of our new odor control innovation, Fresh IQ. Year-to-date, our Basics business is up 2% organically, and we expect momentum to continue through the fourth quarter, as our holiday promotions are in place, and we begin to advertise behind Fresh IQ.
Global Champion for the quarter delivered low single-digit organic revenue growth, driven by low double-digit growth in the mass channel and strong double-digit organic growth in Japan. And in terms of our U.S. online business, sales across all channels increased 17% in the quarter.
The second lever of our business model that drove strong third quarter results was our acquisition strategy. We continue to generate significant synergies from our prior acquisitions, including Hanes Europe, Knights Apparel and Maidenform, which continues to create synergies even 3 years after closing. For the full year, we remain on track to achieve our target of $40 million in acquisition synergies.
We also benefited from the addition of Champion Europe and Pacific Brands. Both businesses drove revenue and operating profit results that exceeded our plan, further reinforcing our excitement about these acquisitions. These are great businesses with great brands and very strong management teams that are already creating value for our shareholders. We remain on schedule with the integration planning, and we're confident in our ability to deliver over $125 million in combined annual operating profit within 3 years.
And the third lever of our business model that drove strong results in the quarter was our cash generation strategy. When we exited the fourth quarter last year, the weather-driven slowdown created an inventory overhang that temporarily impacted our cash flow. While there have been some skeptics, we communicated a specific strategy to reduce inventory and generate record levels of cash flow, and that's exactly what we've done. Inventory in the quarter, excluding recent acquisitions, declined significantly from the second quarter's level, which in turn helped drive $337 million in cash flow from operations. And as we expected, our acquisition and integration expenses continue to decline, all of which keeps us firmly on track to deliver our cash flow guidance for the year.
So in summary, we had a great quarter. And this, combined with our full year outlook, represents further proof that our business model is as strong as ever and continues to create significant long-term returns for our shareholders. Looking forward, we believe we are extremely well positioned to deliver on average mid-single digit revenue growth and double-digit EPS growth for many years to come.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerald. We delivered strong operating results for the quarter. Our sales initiatives reaccelerated organic growth across multiple business lines. Our inventory reduction actions generated record levels of cash flow from operations. Our acquisition
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerald. We delivered strong operating results for the quarter. Our sales initiatives reaccelerated organic growth across multiple business lines. Our inventory reduction actions generated record levels of cash flow from operations. Our acquisitions, both past and present, posted better-than-expected profit results. And our acquisition- and integration-related expenses continued to decline.
Now let me walk you through the specifics for the quarter. Sales increased 11% over last year, and like many diversified global companies, we had various puts and takes across our multiple business lines. Acquisitions contributed nicely as Champion Europe, Pacific Brands and the acquired Champion license in Japan added approximately $180 million of revenue in the quarter. We delivered strong organic growth in several business lines, including Basics, Champion of mass, Gear for Sports, Champion Japan and online. This growth was offset by a decline in Champion in the sports speciality channel as well as a decline in our U.S. direct-to-consumer business, where we are proactively transitioning to a growth model by exiting our legacy catalog business and removing noncore offerings.
Looking at our 2 largest segments, Innerwear sales increased 2% organically in the quarter. Our Basics business was up 9% over last year, including 20% increase in men's underwear. This strong organic growth was driven by our various focus on the core sales initiatives, including increased marketing and promotion as well as the launch of Fresh IQ, the first innovation in our core in over a decade. 
Year-to-date, our Basics business is up 2% with the growth evenly balanced across all product categories. This was partially offset by the expected decline in intimates, as we anniversaried the large pipe of Hanes bras in last year's third quarter.
Turning to our Activewear segment. Sales declined 2% in the quarter. Our Champion business at mass increased by over 10% organically as our refreshed product offering continues to resonate with consumers.
Gear for Sports, which is our college bookstore business, also delivered organic growth in the quarter, up mid-single digits over last year. This growth is more than offset by declines in Champion in the sports specialty channel, due to the bankruptcies of certain sporting goods retailers in the U.S. While we're disappointed with the results in this channel, we believe the headwind is temporary. More importantly, we expect this channel to return to growth in 2017, as our POS trends remain positive at key accounts. We secured new space, and we lap the impact from the bankruptcies.
Switching to margins. Now that our inventory-related actions are behind us, as expected, our gross margins returned to growth in the quarter, increasing 60 basis points over last year, while operating margins decreased 40 basis points, due to the short-term dilution from recent acquisitions. Adjusting for these acquisitions, operating margins increased 30 basis points over last year, driven by synergies from Hanes Europe, Knights Apparel and Maidenform.
Interest and other expense increased roughly $13 million over last year, as a result of the higher debt balances associated with the acquisitions of Champion Europe and Pac Brands.
The tax rate in the quarter was roughly 6%, bringing our year-to-date tax rate to 7%, which is in line with our full year expectation of a high single digit rate.
Earnings per share of $0.56 increased 12% over last year and came in at the midpoint of our guidance range.
Turning to inventory and cash flow. Inventory in the quarter, excluding approximately $173 million from recent acquisitions, declined by roughly $124 million from second quarter's level as our actions to reduce inventory continued to deliver results. This, in turn, helped to generate $337 million in cash flow from operations, a record for any quarter in our history. Year-to-date, cash flow from operations is roughly $300 million higher than last year, which puts us right on track to deliver on our cash flow guidance for the full year.
Touching briefly on guidance. While still within our initial range, we've narrowed our full year outlook. This reflects the expected retailer caution heading into the holiday season. If holiday is, in fact, more robust, then that would represent upside to our guidance. At the midpoint, our guidance now implies approximately 8% growth in revenue, roughly 10% growth in operating profit, approximately 15% growth in EPS and $775 million in cash flow from operations.
In terms of acquisition- and integration-related charges, our guidance of approximately $180 million remains unchanged and represents a decline of nearly $90 million from last year. Looking to next year, despite the addition of nearly $1 billion in acquisitions this year, we expect these charges to take another significant step down in 2017, as we benefit from integration efficiencies and leverage our prior foundational investments.
So in closing, let me end right where Gerald began. We're having a great year, our sales initiatives have reaccelerated organic growth in several of our core business lines. Our acquisitions both past and present are performing extremely well. Our inventory level is declining, and cash flow from operations is already $300 million ahead of last year. Overall, our business is tracking to our plan, and we remain confident in our ability to deliver on our full year guidance.
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to T.C.

headline: Hanesbrands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
